PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kemp (from 24 citizens) and Senator Walsh (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.

(a)outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b)lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c)cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kernot (from 114 citizens) and Senator Vallentine (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will every pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: CPI Relativity
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that pensioners are being burdened with an increase in the cost of living and are receiving no compensation for it. Because the CPI is not specific to the spending patterns of pensioners, a decrease in the cost of living has been shown as 0.1% which therefore cuts out a rise for this September. CPI has shown a negative movement because within its basket of goods, are luxury items that have dramatically decreased in price and therefore cover the increase in basic consumer items that are relevant to the spending patterns of pensioners. Also the wage/tax deals that have occurred between the Federal Government and unions has meant that Australian workers have received an increase in their take home wage but we have seen no counterbalance occur for pensioners.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to negotiate with the Federal Government to introduce a pension CPI measurement that takes into consideration the spending patterns of pensioners. Also that a $4.50 rise be granted to pensioners to compensate them for the wage/tax deals that occurred in January `91.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Determination by the Minister for Social Security of directions under subsection 1237(3) of the Social Security Act 1991 dated 8 July 1991, tabled in the Senate on 13 August 1991, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not spend a lot of time on this motion today as I understand that the Opposition will not be supporting us. We did allow more time so that this matter could be looked into thoroughly, and I must say I am very disappointed now that the decision has been made not to support this motion. However, I do want to make sure that all honourable senators understand what it is that they will be voting against.

PARA.TAB: These directions issued by the Minister under subsection 1237(3) of the Social Security Act 1971 are, I believe, yet another attempt by this Government to fetter the discretionary powers of courts and tribunals. I want to make the point that the directions under discussion are before us in this disallowable form only because of our initiative, an initiative of the Australian Democrats earlier this year, and an initiative that at that time won the support of the Opposition. This forced the Government at least to provide the opportunity to the Parliament to study this document. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, as passed during the autumn session, contained a clause which removed from the review of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal a determination made by the Minister under what was then section 2511b of the Social Security Act 1947 to give directions to the Secretary about the Secretary's power to waive a debt due to the Commonwealth resulting from an overpayment.

At the time the Scrutiny of Bills Committee expressed its concern that this removal of the power to review was being put in place and noted that such a decision by the Minister was also not desirable; that is, section 2511C required the Minister to allow any such decision before Parliament, but there was no provision for either House to disallow the decision. The Australian Democrats and the Opposition were not happy about removing this power from the SSAT. We certainly believe that ministerial determinations should be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. This was also the course of action preferred by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its report on debt recovery under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

I presume in recognition of the potential of the ministerial determinations to significantly fetter the authority of both the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Opposition agreed to support the Democrat amendment to make a determination a disallowable instrument under this subsection. I might add that we had to move this amendment twice and both times it was supported.

On 8 July the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) made a determination of directions under the subsection and issued a notice in which he set out the specific circumstances in which the power of the Secretary can be exercised to waive the right of the Commonwealth to recover a debt owed to it under the Social Security Act 1991. It needs to be clearly understood that, as well as binding the Department, these determinations also lock in the SSAT and the AAT in this particular set of directions.

We have concerns about both the content and the effect of these directions. Before I discuss what these are, I want to make clear what effect this disallowance motion will have, as there has been some misunderstanding in the past when I have endeavoured to disallow a motion. A successful disallowance motion involves both legislative and political action. If the Senate disallows this instrument, it simply ceases to have effect. However, the idea behind the disallowance motion is that, if the Senate has the numbers to disallow the instrument, the Government has to come up with a motion that is acceptable, something that the Senate will pass. In other words, it is a negotiating tool and one that does have some power.

If the Government does not want to be left in a vacuum in the area covered by the disallowable instrument, it must redraft the instrument or regulation fairly quickly and re-present it. In relation to this instrument, it could be withdrawn or redrafted—that would be fine—but it also quite simply could be allowed to lapse because its absence in this case would not leave any vacuum at all. This is because, firstly, the present mechanisms that are in place are adequate and, secondly, the Government could, if it chose to do so, issue these directions as departmental guidelines, thereby restricting their application to the officers of the Department.

I turn to our main problem with the instrument: it undermines the principle of independent review of administrative decisions. Indeed, it represents, as the Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney has accurately noted, an attempt to bind independent tribunals with administrative directions which carry a political agenda. I believe it is very important for the Opposition to see beyond the subject matter of this particular instrument and to look at that. This instrument is part of a pattern of government legislation that I believe is not desirable and may well be highly dangerous.

This particular instrument deals with overpayments made under the Social Security Act. Recovery by the Commonwealth of any overpayment has, of course, always involved the exercise of some discretion. This is understandable. There may well be a variety of factors at work that explain why the overpayment was made. No-one would wish to remove from government the right to issue guidelines about the exercising of that direction. The issue here is whether this Parliament should permit the Government to extend its authority in this area to the SSAT and the AAT.

Over time, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the courts have suggested a number of factors which are relevant in the exercising of that discretion. The intention of the courts is to lay down broad principles around which the discretion can be exercised in a fair manner, taking into account all the individual factors in each specific case. The criteria most often referred to with approval by the AAT and implicitly accepted by the Department are laid down in the 1983 Federal Court case of Hales.

These seven factors set out in the Hales case are: first, the fact that the applicant has received public moneys to which he or she was not entitled; secondly, the way in which the overpayment arose, whether as a result of innocent mistake or fraud; thirdly, the financial circumstances of the prospective defendant; fourthly, the prospect of recovery; fifthly, whether a compromise is offered; sixthly, whether recovery should be delayed if there is a prospect that the circumstances of the person who received the overpayment may improve; and, seventhly, compassionate considerations and the fact that the Act is social welfare legislation and any financial hardship which may result from an action for recovery must be considered.

Under each of these headings the AAT has developed a number of subfactors enabling the tribunal to apply them to diverse individual circumstances. These principles or criteria have proved their operational worth and soundness and it is generally accepted that they are a fair balance between the rights of the individual on the one hand and the public interest on the other. Indeed, in the course of my discussions about this instrument with various interested parties I could not find anyone who believed that these well established judicial principles did not provide an appropriate balance between the Department of Social Security and its clients.

As I have said in this place before, there is simply no evidence that the current system of occasionally waiving debts is not working. Of an annual budget of about $20 billion, about 0.4 of one per cent of this figure is debt owed to the Commonwealth. The Department acknowledges that 80 per cent of overpayments are a result of administrative error and do not stem from any deliberate fraud. Furthermore, in 1989-90 about $2.7m in debts to the Department was waived out of a total of $81.4m raised as overpayments. It can scarcely be argued that there are thousands of social security recipients defrauding the Department of Social Security and then having their debt to the Commonwealth waived by some mischievous people sitting on the SSAT, the AAT or, indeed, the Federal Court.

It is simply untrue to imply that a system is not working and then use that as an excuse to constrain the powers of independent tribunals to make fair decisions. The implicit suggestion behind this instrument is that the tribunals and courts reviewing the decisions of the Department of Social Security are waiving debts inappropriately and improperly. The evidence indicates otherwise. I suggest to honourable senators that it is highly undesirable to allow any government, once a matter has gone to an independent review body, to restrict the ability of that review body to exercise its independent discretion to review the decisions of the bureaucracy.

We all know that this Government does not like it when people dare to disagree. It is a fact that both the SSAT and the AAT often disagree, certainly with the Department of Social Security. The value of having an administrative review system separate from government is not just that courts and tribunals can disagree with government but that persons aggrieved by governmental decisions have a fully independent avenue for seeking redress. This instrument, in conjunction with earlier legislation, sets up a situation where a Minister can issue directions that will directly bind tribunals and limit their ability to exercise their full and independent discretion in a crucial area.

Obviously, we are not suggesting that government does not act to recover debts owed to it. There is nothing to stop the Minister putting forward these criteria as departmental guidelines and binding the DSS officers to follow those. But when these criteria are also applied to supposedly independent tribunals it seems to me that we are getting onto very dangerous and shaky ground. The Opposition has recognised these dangers in the past and I believe should be supporting us and sticking to its principles in disallowing this instrument. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not support the disallowance motion moved by Senator Lees on behalf of the Australian Democrats. This disallowance motion relates to a direction which was issued by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) on 9 July 1991 setting out the circumstances in which the DSS and the relevant appellate tribunals, namely, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, can waive debts or overpayments owed to the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: For the uninitiated, when a DSS debt is waived it ceases to exist. A waiver is a permanent bar to the recovery of the overpayment or the debt. It is markedly different from a write-off, where an administrative decision is made that in the circumstances there is no point in trying to recover the debt. Unlike a waiver, in the case of a write-off the debt still exists and may be pursued at a later date.

Section 1237 of the new plain English Social Security Act gives the Secretary of the DSS and his or her delegates the power to waive the Commonwealth's right to recover all or part of an overpayment of a debt. Before this direction was issued, the DSS based such waiver decisions on non-statutory administrative criteria which flowed from guidelines issued by the Minister for Finance to delegates making decisions on waiver under the Audit Act 1901.

However, both the SSAT and the AAT remained free to base waiver decisions on their own body of case law which had developed over a number of years. The 1983 Federal Court case, Hales v. Director-General of the Department of Social Security, sets out seven factors, which Senator Lees has already outlined, that were considered when deciding whether a debt should be waived. These seven factors became the basis for SSAT and AAT waiver related decisions. I doubt whether the comment that Senator Lees made that the Hales case was accepted implicitly by the DSS is correct.

The different courses taken by the DSS and the two appellant tribunals has resulted in the responsible Minister, Senator Richardson, claiming in a letter to the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that his Department's criteria:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . which were in line with those applying in most other Commonwealth departments and agencies, were undermined over time by successive administrative review decisions. I do not believe that review bodies should be free to operate in this area according to principles of their own devising and so the Minister's directions under subsection 1237(3) should be applied consistently both by departmental staff and the review tribunals alike.

Senator Lees said that this would affect the independent review of a decision. This is not affecting the independent review of a decision. It is saying that those tribunals can make the decision independently but following the guidelines that are given. There is quite a subtle difference in that and that is the difference we have been looking at. For colleagues and senators here, we have been looking at a very fine line. The coalition has taken an enormous amount of advice and has sought to examine this very carefully. We do not believe that the independence is being fettered but that the tribunals can review the decision, given the guidelines, and review that decision independently.

PARA.TAB: In June, the Social Security Act was amended, notably with the support of the Democrats, to ensure that directions such as those being debated here could not be reviewed by either the SSAT or the AAT. The Democrats' reasons for disallowing this direction appear to mirror closely the reasons put forward by the Welfare Rights Unit in a letter to Senator Alston dated 2 October. In this letter, the Welfare Rights Unit expressed four particular concerns in relation to this direction. Firstly, it claimed that the direction would fetter the discretion of tribunals to waive debts. Secondly, it claimed the direction would substantially narrow the circumstances in which debts could be waived. Thirdly, it contended that the direction was based on the false premise that tribunals have gone soft on the recovery of debts and were not interested in deterring fraud. Finally, and of lesser importance, Welfare Rights claimed that the direction did not pay sufficient regard to the special circumstances of assurance of support debts.

Very strong arguments can be made to refute each of the concerns of the Welfare Rights Unit. The `fettering of tribunals' powers' argument, which I referred to earlier, can be refuted by recognising the true role of the SSAT and the AAT. It must not be forgotten that both of these tribunal agencies are reviewing agencies and not courts of law. The SSAT draws its powers from the Social Security Act and its task is to provide independent review of decisions that have been made under that legislation.

It is both illogical and inappropriate that such a body should be allowed to develop its own criteria, by way of case law, for reviewing decisions made by the DSS. If the waiving criteria had been specified in the Social Security Act from the beginning—a move which the Welfare Rights Unit itself has supported—then these tribunals would have had little or no opportunity to diverge from these criteria. The SSAT and the AAT have only been able to develop their own precedents in relation to waiver decisions because the circumstances in which waivers should and should not be granted have not been clearly defined in the Social Security Act.

This brings me to the second important point in understanding the role of these tribunals. It must also be remembered that just as they are not courts, neither are they an arm of either the Government or the Parliament. It is the role of the Government and the Parliament, and not the responsibility of these tribunals, to decide the circumstances in which debts owed to the Commonwealth should and should not be waived. Of course, the Parliament is confining or fettering the powers of these appellate tribunals by the very fact that it is making a decision on this ministerial direction. I ask the Democrats: is this not the role that the Parliament should play?

It is very pertinent to return to the Senate debate which occurred when the idea of such a direction was first mooted. Back in late 1988, the Democrats seemed totally and utterly unsure about whether they wanted the circumstances for DSS waivers to be decided on by the Government through the Parliament. At the same time as Senator Powell moved that this direction should be a disallowable instrument, she also moved that the Secretary of the DSS should only regard—this is very important—such directions. Has anyone ever heard anything so ludicrous?

Senator Powell has proposed that the Parliament waste its time making a decision about whether it will disallow a piece of delegated legislation relating to the use of public money that will not have any legislative strength. At the same time, a review body set up under the very same legislation is free to go off on any tangent it desires.

When refuting this fettering of powers argument, it should also be pointed out that it is very important that the ground rules upon which the decisions are made should not vary between decision makers. No matter whether a decision is being made by DSS, the SSAT or the AAT, it needs to be ensured that affected clients receive equitable treatment based on consistently applied criteria for the waiving of debts.

In effect, this ministerial direction sets in concrete those circumstances in which the Department and the appellate tribunals can waive debts or overpayments. It provides very clear guidelines as to when a debt owing to DSS can and cannot be waived. To this end, this direction can result only in greater consistency, greater certainty and greater equity between decisions in relation to the waiving of social security debts.

Surely the overriding reason why the Minister has issued this direction is to ensure that each and every case that comes before the Department, or either of these tribunals, receives equitable treatment. This direction will ensure that there is consistency in decision making, both between tribunals and the Department and amongst decision makers within the tribunals as well as the Department. It will mean that anyone seeking a DSS waiver will know the specific circumstances in which it can and cannot be granted.

Because these circumstances will be set out in black and white, a person will be able to make a reasonably well-informed decision as to the possibility of having a debt waived. The Department and the tribunals will be able to provide waiver applicants with clear and definitive reasons why they make decisions about the waiving of debts. Further, the setting of clear-cut guidelines will mean that it will be far easier for debtors, their advocates and the Department to assess whether there is a realistic chance of winning an appeal against a decision that has gone against them.

The argument that this direction narrows the circumstances which can be taken into account when deciding whether a debt should be waived can best be refuted by examining its actual content. When considering the fairness of this direction, it must be remembered that the direction conforms with recommendation 13 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of June 1990 entitled Debt Recovery under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlement Act. The recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a client receives an overpayment in the honest belief that it is part of his or her entitlement, and the overpayment occurs solely through administrative error or unreasonable administrative delay, recovery procedures be undertaken only if the department concerned shows that recovery would leave the client in no worse a position than he or she would have been had the correct payments been made.

The Committee's recommendation has been taken up in circumstance (a) of this ministerial direction. Furthermore, legal advice I have obtained points out that the present direction actually refers to the very factors the Federal Court relied upon in finding that recovery of the overpayment should be waived in Hales's case; that is, administrative error, client hardship and the possibility of recovering the overpayment. This legal advice has also concluded that the direction does not make decisions to waive or not unduly depend upon an administrative decision that is not subject to review on the merits by an individual tribunal.

PARA.TAB: It also needs to be pointed out that the direction allows the offsetting of family allowance payments, as recommended by the Senate Committee in 1990. I believe that this is a fair concession. It is not appropriate to offset other unclaimed DSS benefits against a DSS debt for the simple reason that it is not possible to know with any degree of certainty that the affected person would have been eligible for the other benefit.

It should not be forgotten that the direction also contains a special circumstances clause. Quite rightly, these circumstances must be extremely unusual, uncommon or exceptional. For the special circumstances clause to allow a general widening of the scope for the waiving of debts, as the Welfare Rights Unit proposes, would simply defeat the whole purpose of adopting this direction.

When assessing whether this direction passes the fairness test, it is also worthwhile to look at the effect it has had since it came into effect last July. My office has been advised by an officer of DSS that since this direction came into effect there have been nine relevant SSAT cases reported to its national secretariat. In two instances it was found that the SSAT's discretion was confined, but in both of these cases the debt was written off. In three of the nine cases the SSAT agreed with DSS. In two cases special circumstances were found. In the remaining case, the offset clause was used. These early results indicate to me that the direction is both effective and relevant.

At this point, I call on the Minister to continue to monitor those cases to ensure that this direction does not have any unintended consequences that we have not anticipated. I will be asking him to bring in a renewed direction if he sees circumstances in which it is believed that the direction could be changed to alleviate any problems that may not have been foreseen. I notice that the Minister is nodding his head.

The third Welfare Rights argument, which claims that the direction is based on the false premise that tribunals have gone soft on the waiving of debts, can best be refuted by referring to Hales's case. In Hales, both the Federal Court and the AAT held that DSS's failure to regard an annual review statement was the substantial or dominating cause of the overpayment, despite the fact that the respondent had failed to follow DSS's instructions and notify a change of circumstances. This set a very dangerous precedent for DSS. It is worth noting that one of the major differences between this direction and Hales is that the former provides that the debt must be `caused solely by administrative error on the part of the Commonwealth', while the latter allows for a combination of administrative error and client failure. The question is not so much whether the tribunals have gone soft, but whether it was open for them to go soft in a way that fundamentally contradicted DSS's own guidelines.

I assure the Democrats that the coalition has taken this disallowance motion very seriously. However, we are adamant that, when all the arguments have been considered, the only sensible conclusion that can be reached is that this direction should be supported. I wholeheartedly believe that it will provide greater equity, fairness and efficiency in DSS-related waiver decisions. It will result in greater certainty for decision makers, debtors and their advocates. Contrary to the Democrats' claims, it will not result in any great narrowing of the circumstances that can be taken into account by decision makers, nor will it unreasonably fetter the powers of the appellate tribunals. Rather, I believe, this direction will ensure that the waiving of DSS debts is conducted in a more administratively and financially efficient and equitable manner. (Quorum formed)

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the Australian Democrats and the Opposition have both put a considerable amount of time and effort into determining a view on directions. I should say at the outset that the only purpose for doing this at all is to achieve some consistency in decision making, because that is always the problem. I would have thought that anything the Government can do which makes this process more certain for clients and for the Department of Social Security has to be better for all concerned. That is the only purpose involved in the exercise today.

PARA.TAB: The power of departmental staff to waive debts due to the Commonwealth has existed under the Audit Act for a very long time. The exercise of the power to waive is regulated by guidelines under the Audit Act and issued by the Minister for Finance. In general terms, those guidelines require that for a payment to be waived, it must have been made as a result of departmental error and payment must have been received by the debtor in good faith. The exercise of the power to waive a debt under the Audit Act is not open to appeal to appeals tribunals.

Subsection (1) of section 1237 of the Social Security Act provides for the possible waiver of a social security debt due to the Commonwealth. Subsection (3) of that same section permits the Minister for Social Security to issue directions concerning the waiver of social security debts. Subsection (2) of that same section of the Social Security Act makes such ministerial directions binding on the Secretary and his delegates. Paragraph (m) of section 1250(1) of the Social Security Act also makes such ministerial directions binding on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. By extension, of course, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is also bound because it has to work under the same conditions that apply to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

On 8 July I issued the set of directions which are now before the Senate in this debate. These directions are based on the guidelines of the Minister for Finance which apply to Audit Act waiver powers. They are adjusted as required for the specific needs of my portfolio.

It is not just my view but a pretty firm view within the Government that the directions are justified in the interests of promoting the consistency to which I earlier referred.Without these directions, as a matter of law different decision makers can decide, and have decided, similar cases entirely inconsistently. In addition, any two social security appeals tribunals in different States—and even in the same State—can decide two identical cases differently. I would have thought that is not in the interests of clients or the Department and it is not a bad idea for us to do anything we can do to stop it.

Any one social security appeals tribunal, for its own reasons, can decide that it wants to depart from informal guidelines that are followed by the departmental decision makers. Therein lies a real problem. When a tribunal decides to depart from guidelines that it knows the decision maker was operating under, we have never ending examples of inconsistency. That is why we are here today. We need greater certainty and I think the application of consistent and fair guidelines is the only way we will get it.

There are a few points to note in considering these directions. Firstly, the criteria that are set down are general in scope. They are not blanket criteria forbidding any waiver decisions. I am not certain that that has been entirely reflected in Senator Lees's views. The criteria echo what is generally applied in the Commonwealth public administration and are based, as I said earlier, on the guidelines of the Minister for Finance which apply to the Audit Act.

The directions bind the tribunals in the same way as do regulations. There is not much difference between these directions and regulations anyway. They are disallowable by either House; and they have been considered by a Senate standing committee. So, in any event, I would have thought we were talking about a pretty fine line of difference.

If these directions are adopted, they still leave appeals tribunals with the jurisdiction to consider social security overpayment appeals. It seems to me that the directions still address the basic concern in respect of welfare rights. But there is still that power. Few, if any, other departments raise overpayments which can be reviewed by appeals tribunals; they are a pretty rare breed. So I would have thought it is only fair that if the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are to be in that somewhat rare category, they should have to apply consistent principles in resolving their cases.

Like Senator Patterson, I have taken careful note of what has occurred since the directions came into effect. I think they tend to bear out the Government's view, and I understand the view of the Opposition that this disallowance motion should be defeated.

The directions have not, as yet, created any situations that are in the category of unforseen circumstances. On no occasion thus far have I seen the need to alter anything in them. But I accept what Senator Patterson said in terms of the need for continued monitoring. I can undertake to have that not only continued but also reported in the Department's annual report so that every honourable senator can see what has occurred during that time.
I do not believe that these directions have created any problems. I think they have made for better decision making. To use the old adage, `If it ain't broke, why fix it?'.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—The Committee is considering the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee E, which relates to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. We will deal with program 4, `Assistance for People with Disabilities'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put in a reservation about program 4, relating to assistance for people with disabilities. I did so because of serious objections I have, which have been reinforced by others in the community, in relation to this program. I can do no better than quote from a speech given by Mr Brian Corcoran, First Assistant Secretary, disability services program, on 1 September at Mount Eliza in Victoria. I quote from his introductory comments at that conference:

SPEECH.PARA: We are four years into a five year formal transition period, which all would acknowledge has not fully realised the ambitions of the DSA when it was enacted in 1987. The last four years have been a valuable learning period for all the stake-holders involved. Both the Department and service providers now need to reflect openly on where we are at, and jointly on what the prospects are for the future.
Later in his speech he said:

Significant numbers of parents and consumers continue to be concerned about the impact of the Disability Services Act on their lives, and do not clearly understand the rationale of government policy on disability services. In this regard the Department will need to pursue a more active and strategic approach to marketing the program and the benefits it offers. Fear and uncertainty are major inhibitors of development and ones which affect service providers and the Department equally critically, although in different ways.

PARA.TAB: The front cover of the spring edition of the Endeavour Foundation News from the Executive Director's desk has the following heading: `The Federal Budget—An Unexpected Disappointment'. It also states:

SPEECH.PARA: August's Federal Budget has had a devastating effect on the operation of all community based service providers for the 1991/92 year.

The Endeavour Foundation is the largest community based charitable organisation of its type in Australia. It started in Queensland in 1951 and it provides services to some 3,000 Queenslanders with an intellectual handicap. It has 20 branches, with facilities and services at more than 180 locations. In addition, there are 36 sub-branches throughout Queensland. It has clinical support services, assessment and diagnosis services, family counselling, recreational programs and client development programs. This is what the Endeavour Foundation said about the disability support program in the Federal Budget:

The recession has already forced organisations into a position where the emerging needs of people with an intellectual handicap are not able to be met and waiting lists for services grow longer every day. People with the highest support needs and people leaving special schools at the end of this year will be especially hard hit.

In the Federal Budget, all organisations had their Disability Service Programme block grants slashed by 2% without warning. Endeavour's grants have been reduced by $160,000 from the amounts included in the contracts signed only two months ago. To be advised by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services that this reduction was a bureaucratic decision and not to blame the Government is just not acceptable.
As a further consequence to the Federal Budget, there will be no increase in the Invalid Pension this year—this will obviously affect every Client of Endeavour Foundation.
This is a reduction in real terms in disability funding and people may well ask whether disability is helping to pay for the new Federal initiative—the Building Better Cities Campaign.
On top of the recession, it's all bad news for disability services.
What is the Department's reply? The Department's reply from the under secretary is:
The Department will need to pursue a more active and strategic approach to marketing the program.

The Department's reply is to market the program. How can the Minister reconcile these two separate statements? On the one hand, the disability services program is said to be answering the needs of the clients and, on the other, we have the reply from the Endeavour Foundation, the largest community based charitable organisation in Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the moneys made available for the types of activities undertaken by the Endeavour Foundation have not, overall, been decreased. There has been some marginal change to indexation factors, but in fact the Government has continued to indicate its very real support for the betterment of the conditions of those with disabilities in the Australian community. That does not mean that a perfect outcome has been achieved. It is very important that governments listen to such organisations as the Endeavour Foundation.

PARA.TAB: Where critical comments have a base in either the actual delivery of services or in the policy underlying that delivery, I am quite sure that this Government will be open to persuasion that an alteration might be made. There has to be a recognition from both sides of the good faith of each side so that, on the one hand, as I say, there is a proper recognition by government of the sorts of organisations to which Senator Herron refers which deliver services to enable us to be a compassionate and just society as far as persons with disabilities are concerned, and that recognition is expressed in practical support from the Budget. With that goes a recognition that that experience ought to be listened to by government. On the other hand, it is important that these organisations also recognise that the Government, within the constraints of the moneys which taxpayers are prepared to provide, does attempt to ensure that the legitimate needs of those in the community with disabilities are met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Estimates hearings, I asked for a copy of the most up to date figures in relation to the employment of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service. I have since received these figures for over 50 Federal agencies for the period 1989 to 1991. Each agency collects its own figures annually by way of staff questionnaires and then provides its figures to the Public Service Commission, which collates them.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) may recall that I sought and received similar figures at last year's Estimates for the years 1986 to 1989. He may also recall that virtually one year ago today the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services and now Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Brian Howe, expressed his concern in relation to the declining recruitment by the Australian Public Service of people with disabilities. Mr Howe was launching the Public Service Commission's disability information strategy at the National Press Club. The Minister may remember that the Government had allocated $50,000 from last year's Budget for the development of a Public Service wide disability information strategy.

Obviously disgusted by the news that between 1986 and 1989 the base grade recruitment of people with disabilities by the Australian Public Service had dropped from 5.2 per cent to 3.1 per cent, Minister Howe stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I regard as totally unsatisfactory the reported decline in the level of recruitment of people with disabilities into the public service. The Government cannot accept a situation where the public service is operating in a manner that is inconsistent with the broader objectives that the Government has set for the employment of people with disabilities.
In this speech, Minister Howe gave a personal commitment to talk to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters,
Senator Cook, to see `what further initiatives can be taken on this issue'.

PARA.TAB: When I undertook an analysis of these figures of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service, broken down according to agencies, it became patently obvious that the problem to which Minister Howe was referring is occurring virtually throughout the entire Public Service. Of the 50 agencies where comparison could be made between 1986 and 1989, the proportion of total employees with disabilities had fallen in 44 of them. It had risen in only five agencies and remains static in the remaining agency. So in 44 of the 50 agencies it had declined.

On 28 December last year I issued a media release calling for immediate action to arrest this across the board decline in the employment of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service. Considering the strong rhetoric from the highly influential Minister Howe as well as his commitment to seek further remedies in consultation with Senator Cook, I thought I was not being too optimistic in believing that something might be done to improve this totally unsatisfactory situation.
The release of these latest figures shows that, rather than improving, the situation has actually worsened in 1990 and 1991. Between

SPEECH.PARA: 1989 and 1991 it was possible to undertake a comparison of the employment of people with disabilities in 54 Federal government agencies. Of these 54 agencies, 40 reported a decline in their employment of people with disabilities between 1989 and 1991. Thirteen reported an increase while one agency remained static.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the decline which has occurred between 1986 and 1991, one sees that the picture is even gloomier. Over these five years, which coincidentally are also the first five years of the implementation of the Disability Services Act, the employment of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service has dropped in 38 of the 43 agencies in which a comparison can be made. It has risen in only four agencies and has remained static in one agency.
