TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to point out a few of the figures as they pertain to individual agencies. Between 1986 and 1991 the National Museum fell from 13.6 per cent to just 3 per cent; Finance fell from 6.3 per cent to 4 per cent; Industrial Relations fell from 6.7 per cent to 3 per cent; Primary Industries and Energy fell from 10.1 per cent to 6.5 per cent; Social Security fell from 6.2 per cent to 4.3 per cent; Veterans' Affairs fell from 6.9 per cent to 4.9 per cent; Immigration fell from 6 per cent to 4 per cent; and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, between 1988 and 1991, fell from 8.9 per cent to 5.3 per cent.

PARA.TAB: As I said, this is at a time when the Disabilities Services Act which the Government is advocating, with the support of senators and members of this Parliament, is being implemented—implemented with a policy of ensuring that as many people as possible who are able to be placed are placed in open or supported employment.

In fact, the public sector is not setting the example. I think the Minister would agree that this situation becomes doubly unsatisfactory because of the Government's policy in relation to the placing of people with disabilities in open or supported employment. The objective of subprogram 4.2 which we are currently talking about is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: To ensure that people with disabilities have access to, and choice of, wage generating work with job security and opportunities for job mobility and career advancement through a range of vocational services and supports.
An objective with which, I am sure, not one of us in this chamber would disagree.

PARA.TAB: As Minister Howe has stated, the disability task force realised that the bottom line for ensuring that its initiatives would be successful was to increase the access of people with disabilities to paid employment. Minister Howe has also claimed that the disability task force also recognised that the Australian Public Service would have to set an example to ensure that this occurs. It is obvious from the figures that that is not happening.

The disability services program's labour force and disability work force consultancy came to the same conclusion when it brought down the report entitled National Employment Initiatives for People with Disabilities in August 1990. Recommendation 6.6 of this report called on the Commonwealth Government to explore all potential strategies in relation to the development and implementation of EEO and AA programs in both private and public sector employment, including local government, to provide full opportunities for full and equal integration into the general labour market for people with disabilities.

The consultancy's Strategy Six called for a broadly based targeted access program which would be initially implemented in Commonwealth Government departments, statutory authorities and wholly owned government corporations. This targeted access program would address the needs of people with intellectual, physical or multiple disabilities to enable them to gain access to the general labour market.

I can tell the Minister that I consider the Government's absolute failure to address the continuing decline in the employment of people with disabilities by the Australian Public Service to be particularly distressing when one considers the other changes which the Government is currently making in terms of the employment of people with disabilities.

Very relevant to the issue we are discussing is the fact that on 12 November the Government's disability reform package will be implemented. From that date, disability support pensioners will have action plans drawn up for them in a concerted and welcome attempt to help them achieve mainstream employment. The labour market is depressed enough at the moment. Mr Kerin has made it official that we are in the worst recession in 60 years. People with disabilities and their families certainly do not need the added burden of knowing that the Australian Public Service is employing fewer and fewer people with disabilities every year.

Also very relevant to the issue we are discussing are the continuing concerns that are being expressed about the implementation of the transition phase from sheltered workshops to supported and competitive employment. While I applaud the overriding objective of greater integration, it is proving very difficult to put the theory into practice. The problems are only exacerbated when the largest single employer in the country, with over 160,000 employees, is not holding up its own end of the bargain.

To put it bluntly, it is time that the Government realised that, in terms of the employment of people with disabilities, social justice begins at home. It begins at home in the Australian Public Service and statutory authorities. It is all well and good for Minister Howe to claim that in the development of its social justice strategy the Government has given particular attention to the needs and aspirations of people with disabilities, but the Government must back up its rhetoric with action. It must get its own house in order. As I said before, social justice begins at home.

I have a number of questions for the Minister in relation to this important issue. Will the Minister find out what work has been done by the Deputy Prime Minister, in consultation with Senator Cook, to undertake further initiatives to improve the employment of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service since the launch of the Public Service Commission disability information strategy one year ago? A question asked in this House a couple of weeks ago of Senator Cook failed to reveal anything to the Senate about what was being done.Can the Minister give me an undertaking to inform the relevant Ministers—Ministers Howe, Richardson and Cook—about the coalition's concerns in relation to this matter and urge them to take immediate action to rectify this continuing problem?Will the Minister give an undertaking that either he, or the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, will provide the Senate with a full and comprehensive report on the employment of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service over the last five years? Will the Minister give an undertaking that he will provide all the relevant Ministers with a copy of the list of agencies which I have incorporated in Hansard today?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee should be grateful for the work that Senator Patterson has done and for the information that she has incorporated in Hansard, with the approval of the Committee. It clearly is a damning indictment on the Government. It clearly shows that the Government is saying one thing and acting in another way.

PARA.TAB: It is important for this chamber to receive an explanation now from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) as to the Government's action—or inaction—in this regard. Of course, we appreciate that the Minister is not the Minister personally responsible, except for his own Department. I do not know whether the figures show what the situation is in respect of his own Department. If they show something, he may be able to respond to them. The statements made by Senator Herron and Senator Patterson to the Committee deserve a response, and the response should be heard by a committee with a quorum.(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about this matter straight from the heart. I have not any prepared material, but I wish to compliment Senator Patterson on the very fine presentation she gave regarding people with disabilities. I also compliment Senator Herron in this regard. In Queensland I am patron of an Endeavour Foundation at Kingaroy, and I know the tremendous job that the Foundation does within our State.

PARA.TAB: I am also a patron of the Keystone Activity Therapy Centre at Woodridge in Brisbane, a co-patron of which is the Premier's wife, Mrs Roisin Goss. We know the amount of work the centre does in that area. I have been associated with that centre for many years. I have watched the young people as they have become integrated in what is really a very big business in the Woodridge area. It is very good for the people who are there to be able to work together. They are very interested in their work. Only five or six weeks ago I had the opportunity to go to the centre to look at the different types of work it is doing. It has a printing press and many firms in Brisbane give the centre work to do. That type of work involves people working together within their own capabilities—the work force there includes deaf people—and they are being paid some wages for their work. When Keystone started the clients had to pay Keystone to get some work done.

One must realise that the people concerned in the centre have handicaps—they really have got problems—but the Department's theory now is that they should get out into the work force. That is all very well provided that the standards have improved so that such people are able to get into the work force. I understand from Keystone that of 70 clients, only three have had enough ability to be able to go out and compete in the work force. The proposition seems silly when even people who are fit and well at present in this country cannot get jobs. But the Department is suggesting that people with disabilities can go out and compete in the work force.

I suppose that the idea is quite all right, but I do not know how it can be done in practice. The Department is trying to put in place a very difficult process. I also think about the position of the carers of these people, as well as the parents at home, who will find the idea difficult to accept. They care for young people who have handicaps and who are unable to manage as well in the work force as people who have all their abilities; although sometimes employers might say that people who have all their abilities are not 100 per cent in the work force, but that is by the way. Certainly the parents and carers of these people must worry considerably about what will happen to these young people.

I know that the Director of Keystone is doing a fantastic job and that the centre is developing in many different areas. It does woodwork, makes trophies and there are wonderfully capable workers in the organisation, but I believe that they are capable in the area in which they are able to work. To put them out into the broad spectrum of the work force will not help people with disabilities. When they have work to do that is within their capabilities and in which they know their limitations, when they also know the people with whom they work and with whom they have been associated for many years, that is a different matter. But the Department's plan is too ambitious.

Also in Queensland the Department has told the Keystone Activity Therapy Centre and indeed the Endeavour Therapy Foundation that they have to put people into the work force, but the Department itself is not willing to employ people who have handicaps. This is quite wrong. The executive director wrote a letter, to which I added an endorsement, to the Department saying that if the Department is so willing to make these suggestions it should be willing to take action itself and provide some job opportunities. So far, although the Department in Queensland talks about it, it has not been willing to take any action in this regard. This needs to be brought to the Department's attention. If the Department is asking other employers to take on people with disabilities, I believe that the Department itself should also be willing to give an example to other employers.

At the Endeavour Foundation in Kingaroy, of which I am patron, I have watched the people there make the most marvellous biscuits. Indeed, I think that perhaps they could set up a business, and indeed make some pumpkin scones as well to go with them. They have a wonderful clientele who buy biscuits regularly from the centre. The people there take in ironing, and indeed one of my daughters is a customer. They have opportunities to do these things, but to do them within their own area of ability. They are helped and trained by the wonderful people in the Endeavour Foundation and in activity therapy centres—not only the centre in Woodridge but also in various other activity centres in Brisbane and throughout the State. It is important that the Department keeps that in mind for people with handicaps who need assistance and also for their carers.

Those are just some of the things I want to speak about from my heart today. I thought I would take the opportunity offered by Senator Herron's reservation to say a few words and to compliment the people who help these young people, and indeed older people, with handicaps.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was inspired by Senator Bjelke-Petersen's address from the heart. I, too, wish to speak from the heart. I have had experience over 32 years with disability services, in that my eldest daughter has an intellectual handicap. I am appalled at what I see occurring with the Disability Services Act. Two weeks ago I was at Help Industries at New Farm, which looks after 160 people with disabilities. It is governed by a board of retired businessmen and is basically self-supporting. To give an example of what the people there are capable of, they have developed a machine which assembles clothes pegs. This machine is the first of its type in the world. They have a patent on it and in fact they have negotiated and sold one of these machines to Japan. This machine was developed by one of the businessmen as a result of him seeing the rows of people with intellectual handicaps putting together clothes pegs and thinking that there must be a better way of doing it. So he designed this machine and it has been put into effect. It was built on the premises and a world patent has been granted.

PARA.TAB: The Disability Services Act and the Department that controls it wants to close down Help Industries. It is an absurdity. The clients who go there are developed to the maximum of their ability. They are encouraged to go out into the work force. I asked at the Estimates Committee hearing a year ago whether the director of the program had been to inspect Help Industries at New Farm. The answer was no. I was there two weeks ago and the answer was still no. The boffins in Canberra have not deigned to go and see one of the most effective and useful enterprises in this country. The local people have been to see it, but the mandarins in the citadel have not bothered to go and see it. That is one example. The effect of the Disability Services Act will be to close that down.

There is another centre in Brisbane called the Mercy Centre. It has attached to it a commercially effective laundry. In fact, it had the laundry contract to look after the linen for the railways in Queensland. It is staffed primarily by intellectually handicapped women, and a large number of them live on the premises. The effect of the Disability Services Act is that it will not allow what is called backfilling. The way that term is used in the nomenclature sounds as though we are filling in a pothole, but that has nothing to do with the reality of the situation, namely, that if any of the elderly ladies there, or the young ones for that matter, leave the Mercy Centre the nuns are not allowed to fill that position with someone coming onto the premises. They have to be placed somewhere off the premises, and the Mercy Centre has bought houses in the area so that some of these disabled people can live together in groups of four. Social workers come in and take care of them from nine to five Monday to Friday. One can imagine what occurs out of hours and at weekends with severely intellectually handicapped people. There is not the tender loving care on the part of the volunteers or the nuns to look after them.

This is the way in which the Disability Services Act is being administered. It is all very well to have highfalutin ideas and aims. No-one would disagree with them. It is like disagreeing with motherhood. Of course we want these people to achieve their objectives and to be absorbed into the community, but it ignores the reality of the severe intellectually handicapped—some like my daughter who cannot speak—of whom people are saying they should be trained and sent into the work force. It is absurd. I would like the mandarins and the boffins in this sheltered environment, this sheltered workshop of Canberra, to go out into the community and see what is being done by these organisations that are looking after the people and caring for them with that four-letter word—which is not understood by the mandarins and boffins of Canberra—`love'. It is not understood.

This is a cost containment exercise. It is an attempt to shift onto the community people who are incapable of surviving in the community. Senator Patterson has demonstrated the hypocrisy of the whole system when, with all these highfalutin ideas and all the statements about wanting to do what is best for the community, the Department has a mote in its own eye. It cannot even employ people with severe disabilities—or with any disability. The numbers in employment are decreasing, as Senator Patterson has shown with the figures that she produced. That is the hypocrisy of the system and I would like the Minister to respond to this point, which was also raised by Senator Harradine and by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. What is the response to the facts that have been produced by Senator Patterson?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are two aspects to the discussions taking place in the Committee this morning. As to the question of the movement of those people with intellectual disabilities of varying degrees of severity into the more general work force out of what were termed sheltered workshops, drawing on the practical observations and experience not only of Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Herron but also of others who have spoken in the Estimates committees, as well as our general experience out in the electorate from which we are elected—and most of us do get around to the various facilities in the electorate—I think the attention of the Government has been drawn properly to the difficulty, if not the impossibility, of requiring a transition out of these types of work situations to the more general working community.

PARA.TAB: For that reason, it has been made clear that there is no intention on the part of the Government to close down or defund those projects which cannot meet what has been considered to be a proper objective. If that cannot be met, then the organisation concerned will still receive funding for the provision of its services, as long as there is an observation by that organisation of the standards which are expected and which ordinarily are achieved and achieved well above the minimum stipulations set down in the various documents put out by the Department relating to the human rights of the clients of these services.

I would have to agree with much of what has been put to the Committee about the very grave difficulty of putting this objective as though it were able to be practically implemented in a fairly ready way when quite clearly the experience is that it cannot be. Senator Patterson's major matter of concern, in a very full presentation—and I am glad that she delivered it in a fairly slow and measured way so that I could pick up some of the figures, which is her normal way of addressing the chamber—was to point out quite rightly that there has been a slight overall decrease in the number of staff with disabilities employed within the Australian Public Service. That has to be recognised—it is a fact—and Senator Patterson has put that into a form which highlights that fact. One of the difficulties that has to be recognised in using these figures, and the matter of whether a person in the Australian Public Service is categorised properly as being disabled, is a question for that person. In other words, it is a question of self-identification. It may be—I just say `may be'; I am not saying that this would make a huge difference to the figures—that there are some people in the Australian Public Service who do not wish to identify themselves as being disabled. I suppose they might be at the end of the spectrum, which would indicate that they have a less severe disability than some others.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have to do better than that.
—I am coming to some of the points that need to be taken into account. I am not denying the figures.
—Their ability to decide whether they are disabled has changed across the years, has it?
—I suppose they could make a self-description at any time.

—I am saying that it is not a very good argument and would not pass about first or second year psychology, if we are looking at an assessment. If there is self-assessment, the Minister has to put forward an argument that people change their assessment or that there is some reason—that the form has changed or something has changed—for people to be less likely to assess themselves as disabled in 1990 than they were in 1986, for example. The Minister has not put that argument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was only mentioning that as one factor, and I conceded it was a very minor one. The fact is that there will be people within the Australian Public Service who might otherwise be objectively described as disabled but who have not identified themselves as such. It is as simple as that. But the real point is that there has been an decrease—there is no doubt about that. In part, it can be attributed to an overall reduction in the number of base level staff due to the restructuring of departments and streamlining of functions at lower levels, the reduction in suitable jobs due to technological change and multiskilling, and limited regional APS job opportunities due to concentration of the Commonwealth Public Service primarily in capital cities.

PARA.TAB: I am putting those forward as possible reasons: I am not putting them forward as justifications and I am not putting them forward as reasons for allowing the situation the honourable senator has described to continue. To answer her particular question, this has got to the stage where a working party is presently compiling a joint submission to Cabinet on the sorts of matters she has raised. This is being put together by the Department with the Public Service Commission, and I believe that is the vehicle which will be used to try to rectify the sorts of matters which the honourable senator has brought to our attention concerning the employment in the Australian Public Service of people with disabilities.

However, I will undertake to provide to the relevant Ministers concerned, as she requested, the Hansard of this particular debate and the table which she has had incorporated in Hansard. That will be provided, and I will make a personal representation to reinforce the concern which I believe is not confined to one side of the chamber in this particular matter, and in the other matters raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Herron.

As far as providing a full and comprehensive report over the last five years is concerned, I will have to take advice on that. I am not sure what that involves. I imagine it can be provided from figures but I do not know whether they are maintained back that far. I do not think the program has been running for five years but I may be wrong. However, in so far as figures are available to give the honourable senator a longer timespan than the two years that have been the subject of material provided to her to enable her to compile her table, I will see what can be done in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said that there had been a reduction in the Public Service and this was one of the excuses put forward for the reduction in the lower grades. We have just had an increase of 4,000 public servants, as the Minister would be well aware, because there have been numerous criticisms, certainly from the Opposition, that we need an increase in employment in the private sector too, and that the recovery should not really be just led by public servants. Apart from that fact, if there had been an increase of 4,000 public servants I imagine that there would have been an increase in the number of disabled, even in the lower strata.

PARA.TAB: However, the Minister missed a point I think Senator Herron particularly made, and that was that the Department will not close institutions that are badly needed by the profoundly disabled. I am not quite sure what description the Department puts on that because I and other members of a Senate committee which is presently looking at this matter are finding difficulty with the description of some disabled who are unable to be employed. But the Minister ignored completely that ability, which Senator Herron pointed out the Department has refused to acknowledge, to allow backfilling. So these institutions that care for the profoundly disabled are not allowed to backfill— to put someone in who is presently coming up through the school system or through the system. We have profoundly disabled people arriving at the doorstep every day who have not previously needed care but now do. The Government is not permitting the backfilling of those institutions. Therefore, this is a problem which all the institutions bring to us and which must be addressed by the Government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mean to not respond but it is simply one of those matters in respect of which I indicated I would certainly provide the Hansard to the Minister. I believe the question of backfilling is a matter which is quite properly raised by Senator Herron. What he is putting has merit and I believe the Government ought to be sympathetic to the sorts of concerns that have been raised.

—I think we have had a rather fulsome debate on this matter but, rather than fairly weak attempts to argue why those figures might have been reduced, what I would have been expecting from some of the departments would be examples of enclaves that they have set up that are beginning to work effectively, demonstrating the durability of the placement of those people out of sheltered workshops in those enclaves on a durable and ongoing basis. That is the sort of thing that all of us on both sides of this chamber would be expecting from the departments which are implementing a government policy of putting people into open employment.

PARA.TAB: When we say there has been a decrease, each one of those figures is an individual; each one is a person. As I moved around Victoria going to sheltered workshop after sheltered workshop, some expressed their desire to remain in those workshops and a number expressed their desire to go into open employment. If they are to go into open employment, then the Public Service and statutory authorities ought to be setting the example. We ought to be seeing by now first-class enclaves really working and demonstrating and setting an example to the private sector of what can be done. The only evidence I have seen of that was last week when I visited the Portland aluminium smelter. It is in the process of setting up an enclave for 10 people from the school for intellectually handicapped. The company itself, in conjunction with that school, is undertaking some of the work being done at that school at the smelter itself by incorporating those people. There is a whole program being set up to ensure that the staff are prepared and ready to accept those people as they come in.

Let me say that it is a difficult task to do that and we must prepare the work force to accept those people as they come in. They have to be accepted in the staff room and in the workplace itself. I have not seen an example of that and I would be grateful if a department could show me an example of a department doing that. That is the sort of argument that we would want to have put forward. If the Minister has one, then let us all know about it. One swallow does not make a spring. By now we should be seeing quite a few springs and a summer in the implementation of this disability services Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we can go much further on this. Certainly, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made Employer of the Year awards which attracted over 29 nominations from a variety of local, State and Commonwealth organisations. The winner of the national award in the large employer category was a State government body, the Department of Land Administration in Western Australia. Perhaps I can obtain a resume, a short precis or a description of the project or the employment regime undertaken by that employer in Western Australia, that State government body, as an example to put alongside that of the Portland aluminium smelter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Among the reasons or excuses advanced by the Minister, on advice from the Department, for the decline not only in percentage but in the numbers of persons with disabilities in the Public Service was multiskilling. I rise not only as a senator but also as a honorary trade union official to indicate to the Committee that it was the Government which promoted multiskilling as part of the structural adjustments required by the Industrial Relations Commission in its national wage decisions. We were assured that this multiskilling would not affect the opportunities for employment of persons with disabilities. Now the Government is telling us that that is one of the reasons for the decline in the number of persons with disabilities employed in the Commonwealth Public Service. The Government would have it both ways. If that is the advice that has been given to the Government by the Department of Social Security, it had better look at Senator Cook's Department which was supposed to ensure that multiskilling did not have that effect.

PARA.TAB: I come to another question. We have to look at the whole area of disability services in the broad. We have to look at what is happening in the States as well and whether the decisions that are taken by the Commonwealth in this respect have regard to some of the adverse decisions that are taking place in the States.

I refer to my State of Tasmania and to a former electorate officer, Mr Phil Vincent, who is now an employee of a Commonwealth department in Tasmania. Mr Vincent is a cerebral palsy sufferer. He has pointed out that what is to take place in Tasmania is a further discrimination against, a further barrier to, persons with disabilities gaining employment. The State Minister for Community Services, Mrs Judy Jackson, has indicated that there will be a change as from 1 November to what is now known as the transport access scheme, formerly known as the transport and parking concession scheme.

I refer to a report in the Hobart Mercury of Wednesday, 30 October 1991 and to what Mr Vincent said in that report. It is very important that the Minister, the Department and the Committee know, when considering whether the allocation that is before us is appropriate, that from 1 November, I think, the Federal Government's disability allowance is to be increased from $11 a week to $20 a week for persons who are working. From that date, the Tasmanian Government has imposed a means test on its scheme. That means test will result in employed persons with disabilities virtually being prevented from receiving the amount of allowance that they received under the original transport and parking concession scheme.

Mr Vincent said in the report that the Government would not consider someone for the scheme until that person gave up his or her job and went back on an allowance. I ask the Committee whether that is appropriate. Is that a proper policy? Mr Vincent goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme was set up to enable disabled people to get out and about in the community rather than staying at home. . . The changes will seriously restrict our ability to do that.

PARA.TAB: As from this Friday—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, 1 November—
the scheme—known as the Transport Access Scheme—no longer would be provided to disabled people with full-time work.

PARA.TAB: Only disabled people on a government pension would be eligible for the scheme, under which the State Government paid 35 per cent of taxi fares.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Mr Vincent, for example, is not able to catch normal transport. He virtually has no choice but to get taxi transport from his home to work. The report continues:

PARA.TAB: Mr Vincent said the changes would discourage disabled people from looking for full-time jobs, make it extremely expensive for them to get to work and stop many from doing their own shopping and going out socially.
It also meant he might not be able to continue his work with groups which provided support and accommodation to the intellectually disabled.

SPEECH.PARA: One of those groups with which I am associated is the Beni Abbes community. Mr Vincent is a very dedicated worker for persons with disabilities in that community. The report states:
The extra cost for him—
that is, Mr Vincent—
to get to work each week would be $35.

PARA.TAB: Taxis were the only transport for people whose disabilities prevented them from using public transport and driving cars.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise this matter because I think it is important for the Department to be aware of these factors and to indicate what it is doing to make sure that its programs to give a fair go to persons with disabilities, to enable them to enter the work force, dovetail with those of the States. I do not think we can consider these appropriations in isolation from what is taking place elsewhere. It is no good saying that we are giving an extra $9 a week when in fact the State Government scheme in Tasmania is taking away $35 a week.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obviously highly desirable that State and Commonwealth decisions which impact upon the capacity of a person with a disability to enter the work force be coordinated and certainly not contradictory or hostile to each other. It is important that, in so far as it is possible, discussions between officials and Ministers ensure that that undermining of a decision by one level of government is not a feature of our Federal system.

PARA.TAB: No doubt that sort of situation is one of the factors which lie behind the very real necessity for the discussions which are taking place as far as the provision of services to members of the community in Australia is concerned. We need to ensure that the arbitrary historical pattern of funding or providing some services by different levels of government does not lead to the sorts of demarcation problems and contradictory decisions that Senator Harradine has outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister will perhaps know about the situation that I will speak about because it concerns the area which we represent. I am told that a number of beds for the frail aged are being closed at St John's Park Nursing Home. Indeed, the home has been instructed not to take in any more frail aged because the beds it is closing are to be refurbished for younger patients with head injuries.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister will know, there is already concern in the community in Hobart that there are not enough beds for frail aged patients. I am concerned that more beds are being closed and that an instruction has been given that no more frail aged can be accepted at our largest public nursing home. We definitely need beds for the young head injury patients. That is essential. But I do not believe that the way one goes about it is to take beds from the frail aged.

Can the Minister give me the number of beds that are being closed at St Johns? I do not expect the Minister to give me those figures off the top of his head. I have been approached by several people. I thought the Minister may well have been too and that he may have the information. If the Minister does not know, I wonder whether he can find out and tell me how many beds at St Johns's Park allocated to the frail aged are being closed and how many are being taken over for the younger members of the community who have head injuries.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —These are matters for the State Government of Tasmania—it runs St John's Park; it decides on the allocation of beds to various categories. If officers can find that information very readily, I will provide it to Senator Walters. I suppose they can consult with their State colleagues. PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—If there are no further questions on program 4, we will move to program 5, `Therapeutic goods'. Are there any matters to be raised?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter with the Minister which I do not think has received attention as yet, and I think it should. It relates to the Baume review recommendations concerning the exchange of evaluation reports and the acceptance of evaluations in certain other countries.

PARA.TAB: I preface my remarks by pointing out to the Minister that in this area we should appreciate that there needs to be considerable caution. We need to recognise the enormous financial interest that international drug companies have in ensuring the rapid spread, as it were, the rapid sale, of their products. Quite clearly, they are most interested in obtaining approval for their product. It is absolutely essential in whatever we do in this area, whatever the Department does in this area, always to have that aspect in the forefront of our minds.

I refer as an example to the drug Depo-Provera in the contraceptive area. The particular manufacturer was very keen to promote this drug. Indeed, when the conference was called in 1981 by the World Health Organisation's HRP program coordinating committee, the manufacturer was amongst those who were making recommendations for the drug's approval.

If one looks at the toxicology review panel on that occasion, the first name one sees is Professor Michael Briggs. The Committee may recall that it was Professor Briggs who was found to have falsified information relating to the ill effects of the contraceptive pill in research he was doing. That research was being paid for by the American manufacturer of the pill. Frankly, I do not think Deakin University has recovered from that scandal. It should be well and truly in the forefront of our minds that manufacturing companies, certain drug companies, will do almost anything to ensure that their drugs are approved. In the Baume report, the Commonwealth Medical Officers Association comments on page 5:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unwise to assume that foreign regulatory agencies do not have any bias in favour of their own local manufacturing industry and that proper scrutiny of the scientific validity of processes will occur in all cases.
Clearly, the Association is aware of this aspect. I turn now to the specific indications of this report. On pages 22 and 23, under the heading `Evaluation', the report states:

All of the recent reviews of drug evaluation in Australia have recommended the exchange of evaluation reports with countries of similar standards. The PSB review stated: given the high level of success the Australian regulatory authorities have had in recent years, the team would be reluctant to see marketing approval granted automatically on the basis of approvals granted in other countries. However, there do appear to be opportunities available to reduce workloads over the longer term through the exchange of evaluations with those countries with a similar industry structure, population and regulatory standards as ours. Sweden and Canada would seem to fit these criteria best.
On page 25 the report states:
Dr Alex Proudfoot, Principal Medical Adviser of the TGA, is on record as stating that the Swedish agency has lower standards of clinical evaluation than Australia.

It is significant that the Committee should understand that here is a situation which gives a cautionary note. Overall the report seems to promote the view that there should be an agreement between, for example, Australia and Canada, and presumably Sweden and certain other countries. I ask the Minister: what, in effect, will be the result of such an agreement? Would it mean that the approval of the drugs in those countries would result in automatic approval in Australia and, if not, what further conditions would apply? I also ask the Minister to detail to the Committee whether any representatives from Australia will be attending the drug harmonisation conference which is taking place this month in Europe. If so, what briefings will those officers have? Is the Minister aware that this drug harmonisation conference is very strenuously supported by the international major drug manufacturing industries?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the pharmaceutical companies are taking all the caveats and warnings issued by Senator Harradine. I think some of those have some weight. Of course, we are conscious of the desire of pharmaceutical companies to market their products worldwide. But the understanding that I have is that any approval given by a credible authority overseas for the sale and distribution of a particular pharmaceutical will not lead to an automatic acceptance of that approval or judgment of that authority by the relevant Australian authority.

PARA.TAB: It is proposed that the results of an assessment carried out and approval given by an overseas authority will be available for consideration by our regulatory authority, together with the data supporting the overseas authority's determination. But there is no substitution of the judgment of the overseas authority for the judgment of the Australian authority as to the question of whether the pharmaceutical ought to be approved for distribution within Australia.

As to the question of the officials attending the drug harmonisation conference, I am advised that that conference is already taking place and that some four officials have travelled to the conference. I suppose they will be aware, as Senator Harradine is, of the need to be cautious about the fact that marketing strategies of international pharmaceutical companies do not overbear the proper decision making processes in individual jurisdictions which are designed to protect the health and well-being of the inhabitants of that jurisdiction.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns the Prime Minister's new federalism. PARA.TAB: In so far as the honourable senator asked me about practical difficulties, difficulties in relation to both issues have been identified very much in public debate—I think correctly. TALK.START.PARA: —So you rule it out completely, do you?

—You are not doing very well.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to reports this morning that Serbia has again, during the latest round of the peace conference in The Hague, rejected the European peace plan for Yugoslavia. What are the prospects now for Lord Carrington's efforts in light of this latest development? What is the Australian Government's response to the Serbian attitude? What is the current assessment by our Government?

—It is clear that the efforts that have been made to achieve a negotiated and comprehensive settlement are at a rather critical point at this stage. As Senator Loosely has noted, Serbia did again reject the European peace plan when the peace conference run by the Europeans in The Hague convened last night our time. That plan proposed to transform Yugoslavia into a loose grouping of six republics and had been supported—or at least not opposed—by the five republics other than Serbia.

PARA.TAB: In rejecting the plan as it did last night, Serbia is understood to have proposed instead a plan for border changes within Yugoslavia that would have allowed Serbian minorities in other republics to take their territory with them into a redefined and Serb-dominated Yugoslav federation. The Republic of Montenegro seems now to have supported that Serbian proposal, whereas previously it had not opposed the EC plan. But it was rejected by the other republics, not least for the serious implications it would have had for their current territorial status. So there does seem to be an impasse.

After the break-up of yesterday's round of talks, at which Serbia and Croatia did agree on yet another cease-fire, Lord Carrington warned participants in the conference that if that cease-fire failed to hold he proposed that next Friday—that is, in a couple of days time—the conference be adjourned indefinitely. EC Foreign Ministers indicated a couple of days ago, on 4 November, that economic sanctions against Serbia would be considered on Friday, when Lord Carrington is due to report to them, if there was a continuation of the refusal to endorse the peace plan. I understand that EC Ministers are now looking at the possible suspension or termination of the benefits under various bilateral agreements which presently exist between EC and Yugoslavia and, specifically, the possibility of an oil embargo. Of course, that may well be the most effective form of sanction because, whereas Croatia has some domestic oil production capacity, Serbia is almost wholly dependent on oil imports.

As to our governmental reaction, we have consistently and repeatedly made known, both in public statements and in direct communications to the Europeans, our support for the EC peace efforts. There is no doubt in the minds of European leaders of Australia's support. While we are obviously not a party principal to the negotiations in The Hague, we do of course support any peace proposal which is agreed to by the parties directly involved. No such plan should be allowed to founder on the basis of rejection by one republic—or two republics if one brings Montenegro into it.

What the EC is essentially looking for from Australia and other like-minded countries are supportive measures. I indicate again, as I did yesterday, that the Australian Government stands ready to participate in any measures in line with those being considered by the EC or the UN Security Council. The Government's position is also well-known to the parties on the ground. Our Embassy has consistently made our views known directly to the Serbian authorities. But, in case there is any misunderstanding at all in light of the latest developments, I have this morning instructed our Ambassador in Belgrade to make quite clear, yet again, that we firmly believe that a solution to the situation in Yugoslavia must involve compromise by all the parties involved—in particular right now, the Serbs—and that we are deeply concerned at Serbia's rejection of the EC peace plan and will have no option but to support international sanctions against Yugoslavia if they are put in place. We will also, of course, keep the Europeans up to date with our reaction, as we have done consistently until now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I further ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate, in order to try to clear up the ambiguity in the answer which he gave to me a moment ago in relation to the new federalism and Commonwealth-State tax sharing powers: what is the Commonwealth's current position? Does it have a position on the sharing of tax powers between the Commonwealth and the States which it intends to put to the Premiers Conference? If it does have such a position, what is it?
—I do not know whether Senator Hill understands the subtleties of all this, but the Government's position will be put in consultation with the Premiers, not in answer to a question from Senator Hill.

—Once again I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to Mr David Lockwood's wind analyses of the proposed operation of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport with a third runway. Mr Lockwood estimates that downwinds, as distinct from cross-winds, which were covered in the Minister's last answer on this subject, will require 23 per cent of traffic on the north-south runways to operate in a northerly direction. Is this estimate double the estimate in the EIS? Does Mr Lockwood's analysis also show that cross-winds will require the east-west runway to be used by 1.9 per cent of traffic—much more than the 1.2 per cent estimate in the EIS? If Mr Lockwood's analysis is correct, would the 2,000 diversions of large aircraft away from Sydney each year as a result of downgrading the east-west runway be acceptable? Finally, do the predicted reductions in numbers of people affected by noise, previously quoted by the Minister from the EIS, depend on the accuracy of the EIS estimates of both usage of the east-west runway and direction of traffic on the north-south runways?

—The answer to the last part of Senator Faulkner's question is yes, they do depend very heavily on that fact. That is why the information on winds is crucial to the viability or otherwise of the second parallel runway at Sydney Airport. I have found the answer I gave to a similar question on 16 October. I did give a very detailed technical response to the question then, so I will not repeat that and bore everyone to tears a second time. Instead, I refer Senator Faulkner to that answer.
—Wake up to yourself.
—Is Senator Kemp speaking to me or to Senator Faulkner?
—Senator Faulkner.

—That is all right then. I did say in that answer on 16 October that I would meet with Mr Lockwood. I subsequently did so, and I also met a number of other people who were with him. Arising from that meeting, I arranged for Mr Lockwood to have complete access to any civil aviation officers he wanted to speak to so as to check the accuracy of his information. He did that. Mr Lockwood met with officers of the Department in Sydney on 28 October.

PARA.TAB: I reassert the fundamental flaw in Mr Lockwood's analysis. He has set up an entirely theoretical model based on his experience of meteorological matters. In the past, Mr Lockwood has been the director of marine policy for the New South Wales Department of the Environment. I do not dispute that he knows a great deal about wind, but he knows nothing about the operations of an airport. As I said on 16 October, and I reassert that it is important, the EIS is based on actual meteorological observations from the tower at Sydney Airport, not on a theoretical model, as Mr Lockwood's work is.

Mr Lockwood met with officers on 28 October. It was explained to him that the criteria of five-knot tail winds and 25-knot cross-winds for runway usage are well below the safe operating limits of most modern aircraft. It was also explained that the pilot is ultimately responsible for deciding what operation is safe and that air traffic control does not direct pilots to use runways if the pilots have doubts about the safety of the operation. The pilot is in command. Mr Lockwood's assertion about safety being prejudiced by CAA cross-wind criteria for runway selection is therefore entirely unfounded.

The ATC also explained to Mr Lockwood how wind velocity is observed at the airport and used to decide which runways will be utilised. He was presented with 10 years of data collected from the control tower that show an actual long term useability of the north-south runway of 84 per cent, which is significantly higher than the theoretical figure of 76.8 per cent asserted by Mr Lockwood. This shows the danger—and I stress it again—of relying on theoretical assessments that totally ignore the actual operating conditions of the airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does Senator Faulkner keep raising the matter?
—It is an important matter. I notice that Mr Lockwood has got another big run in the Sydney Morning Herald today with this stuff, and I think it is important to get the facts straight.
—Do you think it should blame it on Senator Faulkner?
—No, I do not think the newspaper should show any bias. It should just publish the facts, as all good newspapers do.
—Including the Northern Territory News?

—Apart from the Northern Territory News. The EIS is based on actual rather than theoretical observations. Mr Lockwood was also given four years of data relating to the times the cross-wind runway was used when weather conditions precluded the use of the main north-south runway. I would have thought that that was the most fundamental piece of information on which to rely.

PARA.TAB: For the years 1987 to 1989, 3,392 aircraft per year—that is, 1.7 per cent—utilised the east-west runway when the cross-wind, including gusts, on the north-south runway exceeded 20 knots. However, under the new procedures, aircraft use the east-west runway when the cross-wind, including gusts, exceeds 25 knots. That is because of the additional capacity of modern aircraft. In 1990, this meant that 1,178 aircraft—that is, 0.2 per cent—used the east-west runway. These actual figures are substantially lower than the theoretical figures Mr Lockwood asserts are likely.

The data collected at the airport casts substantial doubt on the value of a very theoretical study done with no appreciation of the practice of airport operations. Far from confirming Mr Lockwood's findings, they show the study to be totally out of touch with reality. It should be noted that the proposal by the FAC eventually to reduce the operational length of the east-west runway will occur only if the airline industry is in agreement, and it will occur beyond 2010 when alternative runway capacity is available at Badgerys Creek on those limited occasions when there may be excessive cross-winds at Kingsford-Smith.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. As the viability of the third runway proposal depends on the EIS estimates in these areas, can the Minister ensure that an independent investigation, consulting with Mr Lockwood, is undertaken into these issues before a final decision is made on the third runway?

—The answer is no. As I have already explained, I agree with Senator Faulkner. I said, and I say again, that the viability of the third runway very much depends on this fact. I have personally met with Mr Lockwood. I organised for him to meet with CAA officers who run the control tower at Sydney Airport, which he has done. Both the CAA and the Bureau of Meteorology have extensively re-examined and analysed the data that has been produced by Mr Lockwood, so I see no further need for an additional study.

—Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen recent media reports of Indonesian troops raiding the Motael Roman Catholic Church in Dili, East Timor, at 2.30 a.m. on Monday, 28 October this year, shooting two youths dead and arresting between 20 and 40 others, because of local opposition to Indonesian rule of East Timor? What has been the Australian Government's response to a request from Amnesty International for an official investigation into the incident, including the deaths of the two youths and reports of detention? Does the Australian Government intend to raise the matter of human rights in Indonesia and East Timor with the chief of Indonesia's armed forces, General Try Sutrisno, during his current visit to Australia?

—I am familiar with the media reports concerning the incident in Dili on 28 October. I instructed the Australian Embassy to investigate that matter as a matter of urgency both with the Indonesian authorities and with independent non-government sources, to the extent that we could get access to them.

PARA.TAB: The information we have obtained from these various sources is inconclusive. The official military account is that the deaths occurred in the context of a fight between Timorese groups outside the church—which may have had something to do with a fight between supporters and opponents of integration—and that two people died in the incident in question. A number of eyewitness accounts suggest that shots were fired. There certainly was a military presence at some stage of the proceedings, but there do not appear to be any eyewitness accounts suggesting that the deaths occurred directly as a result of the shots being fired.

The Indonesian authorities have conceded that shots were fired but say that that was in the context of breaking up a brawl or a subsequent reaction to the situation rather than the cause of the deaths in question. We are continuing to make inquiries about this to see whether a more conclusive, final account can be given in which everyone can have confidence. It does seem that the situation is a little more complex than some of the initial reports sourced in Amnesty and elsewhere. There is absolutely no reason to believe at this stage that the deaths were as a result of direct military or official action.

Of course, if it is revealed that human rights abuses did take place in this context I will instruct our Ambassador to make representations to the Indonesian Government, as we have done on numerous previous occasions. We have consistently emphasised our support for international observance of human rights, both generally in Indonesia and very specifically in the context of East Timor.

I will not be able to meet General Try Sutrisno during this visit to make those points. The discussions he is having are about more specific military matters in a general bilateral and regional context. I am just not sure what points are being made, but I will take that up with Senator Ray and see what might be possible in that respect.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United States Joint Facilities in Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the foreign policy implications of future uses of Nurrungar and Pine Gap. What will the situation be in terms of US-Australian consultation on the next occasion that the US uses the joint facilities in a regional war situation such as the Gulf war, if that particular war is one that the Australian Government does not approve of—a long shot, I know, but one has to live in hope of these things being possible? If information sharing from the bases is extended, would Australia have power of veto if, for example, the Soviet Union decided to use its missile capability against one of its own republics in the event of internal conflict? Further, does the current proposal with the Soviet Union extend to the British, the French and the Chinese, along with other countries concerned about proliferation of ballistic missiles?

—Senator Ray answered a question yesterday on this subject in terms which indicated that, although some information sharing in relation to information derived from these facilities might be in contemplation as part of the general approach to these matters in the aftermath of the Bush and Gorbachev statements, that has not been specifically pursued yet and, if it is pursued, it will be in consultation with us. The Americans have made that perfectly clear. It is premature to embark on a kind of speculative extravaganza about the various contexts in which information might be shared in the future.

PARA.TAB: The facilities are joint. There is no question but that Australia very definitely has joint control over the physical access to the institutions as a result of our joint management of them. There is equally no doubt but that the information sharing aspects of the facilities and the use of the facilities are, again, matters in respect of which joint consultations can be reasonably expected to occur. I am not going to speculate in relation to a variety of hypothetical contingencies in the future on this subject. We will just wait and see how things pan out.

The important point to be made, as Senator Ray did yesterday, is that the facilities in question have an important role not so much in the context of war fighting as in ensuring that that does not happen because of their capacity for surveillance, their capacity for verification and their capacity for advance warning which, of course, constitute a significant deterrent in their own right.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and refers to the equal pay unit which has been set up in his Department to advise the Government on pay equity issues. This unit has just published its first newsletter. What has been the response to this and what does the unit plan to do to continue its obligation to promote awareness of pay equity matters in the community?

—I welcome this question because I am sure that the Senate is concerned to know that the equal pay unit set up by the Government is part of our social justice strategy aimed at getting a fair distribution of the economic resources of Australia and equality of access and opportunity for all Australians, particularly for those who are discriminated against.

PARA.TAB: We set up our equal pay unit as part of the Government's labour market reform strategy and in recognition of the fact that the Department of Industrial Relations needs to be in a position to provide advice on equality of opportunity, particularly in pay, and promote community awareness about pay in equity. The equal pay unit helps the Commonwealth and did so most recently in preparing our national wage case submission. It provided advice on workplace bargaining which ensures that there is no discrimination when we move to that area of bargaining.

The newsletter referred to in the question is published by the unit. It addresses a couple of important key matters. First, it shows that women's rates of pay have increased at a faster rate than men's in recent years. This is due in part to the minimum rates adjustment process that this Government supported in previous national wage case decisions. It means that women can be evaluated on the basis of skill, competence and responsibility whereas in the past those assets may not have been properly evaluated in the pay setting approach. Unfortunately, it also shows, however, that average weekly earnings for full time females employed in the work force are still only 81 per cent of average weekly earnings for full time males employed in the work force.

This newsletter is on distribution to employer organisations and to employers directly, to unions and to women's groups. Over the next three months there will be three other publications from the pay equity unit. They will be in the form of an information paper on the minimum rates adjustment process so that people know how better to utilise this pay fixing principle. There will be a statement of policy on equal pay and the third publication will contain the submission of the Department of Industrial Relations to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission's inquiry into sex discrimination in overaward payments. I commend this newsletter to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the Government's deal with the Solicitor-General which will allow him to take a year's leave on full pay, apparently to practise in the private profession. How does the Government justify agreeing to such a blatant rorting of the system when so many Australians are suffering under this Government's incompetent economic management? Was the Solicitor-General's package renegotiated recently and did any such renegotiation retrospectively increase his leave entitlement to the equivalent of nine weeks per annum, or has it always been that way, and has any of this nine weeks been used thus far? Lastly, will the Solicitor-General be able to return from this quite extended period of leave to work for not much more than one more year and then, if he wished, resign from the job and collect a further windfall of one year's salary in lieu of long service leave?

—I understand that Dr Griffith has been granted leave of absence for one year commencing on 1 January next year. I understand that the period of leave he is taking will be taken from his existing leave credits—that is, the credits he has built up during the currency of his appointment which has been in place since 1984. I understand in general terms that the sorts of leave entitlements to which Dr Griffith is entitled, and in particular his entitlements in respect of leave of absence, are the same or much the same as those on which a judge in the Federal Court holds office. That has been the model which has been used.

PARA.TAB: The period of leave that Dr Griffith is taking will be taken from his current leave entitlements. He will therefore continue to receive full remuneration, including the Canberra allowance. This allowance forms part of the Solicitor-General's total remuneration package and would normally be paid during periods of leave. During this period of leave, Mr Dennis Rose, Chief General Counsel, will be appointed to act as Solicitor-General.

As permitted under section 9 of the Law Officers Act, the Attorney-General has consented to Dr Griffith's engaging in private practice as a barrister during this period of approved leave. Dr Griffith will, nevertheless, continue to perform the duties of Solicitor-General in connection with the Special Committee of Solicitors-General, cases brought against Australia in the International Court of Justice by Nauru and Portugal, and the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law. He will also remain generally available to the Attorney-General and his Department for advice and consultation, without additional remuneration.

As to some of the more specific questions asked of me in relation to Dr Griffith's position should he return at the end of this period of leave and remain as Solicitor-General for a one-year period before resigning or retiring, I will have to seek further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister simply assure the chamber that, in coming back with that additional information, he will refer to one other aspect of my question to which he did not refer in his answer, namely, whether recently the Solicitor-General's contract has been renegotiated and whether any such renegotiation has brought to the Solicitor-General any retrospective benefit, especially as it may relate to annual leave entitlements? Will the Minister also say whether any of that annual leave entitlement, which I think is about 360 days, has been taken thus far in the eight years that the Solicitor-General has had the job—or is he asking us to believe that he has never had a day off? Obviously the Minister will clarify the situation as to whether Dr Griffith will be able to return for not much more than a year, quit the job and take another year's full pay.
—I will have the Hansard of both the original question and the supplementary question examined so that all the points raised by Senator Vanstone are answered.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister confirm media reports that representatives of North Broken Hill Peko Ltd told a meeting attended by him yesterday that their proposal for a new pulp mill in northern Tasmania is economically borderline? Secondly, does the Minister accept that this assessment is consistent with the generally depressed state of the world pulp and paper market, and comments made in February this year by Harris Daishowa's General Manager, Mr Peter Went, that a new pulp mill would be viable only if logging royalties were abolished? Finally, does the Government propose to alter its proposed resource security legislation to include compensation provisions and relax the environmental assessment requirements, as stipulated by North Broken Hill as outstanding issues to be resolved before new investment could proceed?

—A company such as North Broken Hill has to consider a number of matters before a decision to go ahead with an investment of the size of the pulp mill proposed is made. These include the economic viability in terms of rate of return on investment, the strategic position of North Broken Hill in relation to other players in the world market, and so on.

PARA.TAB: On the question of economic viability alone, the proposal is economically important and complex because of its very significant size. As such, the economic viability of a range of variables, including the macro- and micro-economic environment, resource access, quality and price and environmental requirements, is important. So there are many factors to be taken into account in determining the project viability in the light of an investment of this size.

Senator Coulter also referred to the generally depressed state of the world pulp and paper market. The state of the world pulp and paper market varies from time to time. Three years ago there was a very good window of opportunity for substantial investment. A window of opportunity will occur again in, I think, the next few years.

Long term investments of this size and nature are based not on short term assessments of the market but on long term strategic assessments of competitive place in the world and long term trends in the price of the product. The assessment procedures currently agreed between the Commonwealth and Tasmania and the length of time taken to construct the mill after a permit to construct it is issued are relevant matters. This mill would not be entering the world paper market for at least four years, even if the assessment process were begun now. So the current state of the world market is not of particular relevance. There is no suggestion that a project of this kind would be supported by exempting the mill from State logging royalties.

In the third part of the question I was asked whether the Government proposes to alter its proposed resource security legislation. Discussion about some details in relation to the legislation is continuing to take place. North Broken Hill raised a number of issues relating to the proposed legislation but there was no question of the Government being asked to relax any environmental assessment requirement. The issue raised by the North Broken Hill company will be considered before the Bill is finalised and introduced into the Parliament for debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer a very simple question: is the investment by this company contingent on the passage of the legislation; and, given the passage of the legislation, is there a guarantee in place from the company that it will invest?

—The investment is certainly contingent on a number of factors, to which I referred in my answer, including legislation of this kind. The second part of the question is extraordinary because, of course, there is no commitment to make an investment of this kind until some security is given in respect of that investment in relation to a variety of issues, all of which I referred to in my main answer to the honourable senator's question.
