—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to the resolution taken at the special meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council in Melbourne to ban the import and sale of all military and military-style semi-automatic firearms throughout Australia. Does the resolution cover the resale of military-style semi-automatic firearms in private possession that may be sold `privately'? What progress has been made by the special meeting towards establishing a national gun law?

—I can in fact confirm that recently there was a very constructive meeting held in Melbourne of the Australian police Ministers which enabled Ministers from all jurisdictions to put aside political differences, which seems to be an inheritance of this Commonwealth deriving from the States and Territories having borders which can at times lead to different laws in relation to such an important matter as gun control throughout Australia. I believe Senator Gerry Jones has been a persistent asker of questions on this subject, asking very constructive and creative questions on this matter, and that is why I am able to surmise the type of question the honourable senator was asking. It would relate to the police Ministers conference which made it very clear that we are changing the philosophy of the ownership of guns in this society. That is to say, the possession of guns and firearms in this society is a privilege and not a right. This is a very fundamental philosophical point agreed upon by all Ministers and which has enabled us to establish a common position on licensing of firearms throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: This is a very important advance in Australian culture in relation to the culture of violence which needs to be confronted. I believe the question of a common licensing system will go a very long way indeed to ensuring that the possession of guns in our community is only the entitlement of those who satisfy the community that they have a good and genuine reason for the possession of a particular category of firearm.

It was also very notable at that meeting that in relation to domestic violence there was agreement that in all instances where police are called to a situation of domestic violence—which is better described as criminal violence in the home—firearms would be removed and the licence of the holder of those firearms would be cancelled. This would certainly apply during the currency of any protection order granted in relation to the person who made the complaint and who was perhaps the subject of assault or intimidation during that episode of domestic violence.

I believe the meeting was extremely constructive. It enables us to go forward to the Special Premiers Conference and obtain endorsement at the highest political level in this nation for a new regime Australia-wide relating to guns which will set the scene so that we do not slide into that gun-ridden violence which characterises so much of United States society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the call by the ACTU President, Martin Ferguson, for the Government to increase job prospects in Australia. How does the Minister reconcile the action by Western Australian mining unions at Western Mining Corporation's operations at Kambalda in creating obstacles preventing the commencement of continuous underground mining and sacrificing 150 jobs?

—Western Mining Corporation's Kambalda nickel and gold mines in Western Australia have been subject to industrial unrest recently as the result of management proposals to bring about work reform at the mine by introducing continuous rosters for underground mining. That question of continuous rosters for underground mining is a matter for the Western Australian Government. On 4 November the Western Australian Government agreed to grant Western Mining Corporation seven applications for exemptions from the Mines Regulation Act so as to allow continuous operations in the Kambalda mines. Senator Panizza may or may not know that it is a provision of the Western Australian Mines Regulation Act which was the basis of Western Mining's objection and not an award of the Commission and, more specifically, not the activities of the union but a provision of the Act of the Western Australian Parliament.

PARA.TAB: However, the Western Australian Government has agreed to grant those exemptions. The workers involved are employed under awards not in the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth; they are employed in the jurisdiction of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In that case, there is no role for myself as a Minister in this matter but, as the honourable senator pointed out in his question, the matter is now, as I understand it, brought to a conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister advise the Senate what benefits are likely to flow to Australia from the development of a magnesium metal industry in central Queensland?

—There are many very well informed views about the potential use of magnesium metal for environmental reasons, particularly in industries such as the international motor vehicle industry. Magnesium is a strong but very light metal which will be increasingly used by industries such as the Japanese and European automotive industries for structural components in cars. It is lighter and it has beneficial environmental effects in terms of lower fuel usage, and so on.

PARA.TAB: In so far as Australia is concerned, there are outstanding deposits of magnesite ore which constitutes the raw material from which magnesium metals are produced. The CSIRO, in conjunction with some others, has been for some time involved in research into the process for making magnesium metals. The current methods employed overseas have been unavailable to Australia because of the control of the technology by a major company in the United States and a major company in Europe. Therefore, if Australia is to obtain the benefits of adding value to the resources it has, it is very important that the research work of CSIRO, in conjunction with three companies, be carried forward to the pilot plant stage. Because of this situation, the Government has recently made a decision to support CSIRO in the development of an appropriate pilot plant.

The essential issues are the capacity to develop a value added industry based on a very important raw material, a resource. Secondly, there is the matter of the control of the technology in Australia and a very considerable wish that the technology not be lost to overseas companies which would not be interested in adding value to the resource in Australia.

These are the bases of the Government's recently made decision. There are other reasons for it as well. The question appropriately comes from a Queensland senator because the deposit is located near Rockhampton and some of the work has been carried out in Gladstone. The new pilot plant will be built, as I understand it, at Gladstone by a joint venture comprising two Australian companies, CSIRO and a Japanese company. This is a very encouraging prospect for north Queensland and for a major future industrial development in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In light of the fact that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, has today thrice denied his Prime Minister, does the Minister condemn Mr Keating for his efforts to overthrow the Prime Minister?
—I am not sure that is within the Minister's responsibilities.
—I do not think it is either.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I should ask the question about the fall in interest rates that the Opposition should have asked today. Instead, I will direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I draw the Minister's attention to the number of lives saved at sea by the use of emergency position indicating radio beacons, EPIRBs, which utilise satellite technology to pinpoint the position of craft in distress or survivors of a marine casualty. Will the Minister indicate whether this vital piece of safety equipment will be made mandatory on all craft?

—This is an important question, considering the extraordinary number of people who do not seem to see a problem in spending up to $60,000 on a boat and trailer with a couple of 100-horsepower outboards hanging off the back but will not spend $200 on a piece of equipment that has now achieved a spectacular record—
—You answered this question a month ago.

—Yes, but I am going to update that information. Senator Panizza should be interested in the statistics that are being produced. These very successful devices not only produce a great deal of additional safety for the occupants; they also substantially reduce what is often the considerable risk under very hazardous conditions for the people who search for those who are lost and they substantially reduce the cost of the rescues.

PARA.TAB: Since the commencement of the system in September 1989 and the last time I reported to Parliament on this matter, about 70 lives have been saved. We now know that 157 lives have been saved by these beacons. Again I stress the advisability of people equipping themselves voluntarily with these beacons. I am pleased to say that governments around Australia, including at long last the Northern Territory Government, which originally opposed this proposal on the astonishing ground of cost, have now indicated their intention to introduce legislation to require the carriage of these devices. They have saved 157 lives.

As far back as July 1988, State and Territory transport Ministers agreed in principle to legislate for mandatory carriage of EPIRBs, provided the Federal Government installed the ground terminal to access the satellite monitoring system. We did install that ground terminal in Alice Springs. While the Federal Government has met its obligation, I regret to say that to this point only New South Wales has appropriate legislation in place; other States are at various stages in meeting their side of the bargain.

At the last meeting of State and Territory transport Ministers, the Australian Transport Advisory Council, held in October of this year, the Federal Government reminded the States and Territories of their three-year-old obligation. The meeting reaffirmed its intention for all State and Territory governments to progress legislation as quickly as possible. I am pleased to say that at this stage most States are now close to implementing the legislation. As I noted, even the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works, Mr Fred Finch, who originally opposed this proposal on the ground of unreasonable cost to the boat owners, has in the past few weeks indicated a change of heart on the part of the Northern Territory Government and has indicated that his Government will now legislate for the mandatory carriage of EPIRBs. These devices cost only between $215 and $235, which is a very cheap price to pay for a piece of equipment with life saving potential.

I did mention on earlier occasions in the Senate the saving in the often considerable cost to the taxpayer of mounting rescue missions to save people at sea. I asked for advice on the comparative costs of rescues carried out in circumstances where an EPIRB was not carried and where an EPIRB was carried, allowing aircraft to go directly to the spot. Honourable senators may be interested in these figures. In terms of the most recent comparable rescues normally requiring both aircraft and helicopter services, where an EPIRB was carried the cost to the Government was $16,000 compared with costs of up to $200,000 for rescue of craft without an EPIRB.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in response to two questions without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to new federalism.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Senate for giving me this opportunity. I raise the matter at this time because it is of vital importance. The Federal Government has now stepped back from its willingness to give the States a new capacity to raise taxes, which of course was linked with the promotion by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of new federalism as part of an important structural reform resulting in greater efficiencies for Australia. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) might yawn. I suspect that is the attitude of the Government to this matter. But it is related to the whole issue of the requirement for structural reform in this country and, therefore, the need to produce greater efficiency to enable Australian producers to become more competitive.

PARA.TAB: After the July Premiers Conference, Mr Hawke and Mr Kerin had no concern about going public and saying that they would look favourably upon a transfer of new taxation powers to the States. What has happened in the meantime that has changed their minds? Clearly, what has happened relates to what we referred to in Question Time as the whole paralysis of leadership that faces this Government. What has happened is the intervention by Mr Keating. The Minister scoffs; Senator Gareth Evans yawns. This is the typical attitude of this Government to the need for new efficiencies in this country. In fact, Mr Hawke was prepared to—

TALK.START.PARA: —A typical reaction to your speech. You should see what your own back bench is doing.

—Mr Deputy President, are you going to give me any protection? Mr Hawke was prepared to advance this as the flagship of his fourth term in office—this new federalism, the new relationship between the States and the Commonwealth that would break down the structural inefficiencies that have existed for so long. He promoted it, and he promoted it after the July Premiers Conference.

PARA.TAB: What changed? The change occurred on 22 October, when Mr Keating, taking the opportunity of the Prime Minister being out of the country, decided to weigh in and attack the Prime Minister's position. Mr Keating did so, describing the Prime Minister's position as a disaster. At the National Press Club he said that it would gut the Commonwealth. The following day Mr Keating took up the favourite commentator's program, that of John Laws, and said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . federalism is a very broad label, there is a sense of rationalisation of functions but there is no sense in giving revenue back to the States, none.
. . . this change will go on to haunt Australia forever, that is developing six fully resourced State Governments able to rely on their residual powers.

. . . at the threshold of us re-entering the big international scene and the big international debate and the international world of commerce we chop Australia into six governments. I mean, it is just not a goer in Australia.

That position happened to be the one Mr Keating had taken at previous Premiers Conferences when he was Treasurer. He has clearly been long opposed to the issue of either transferring new taxation powers to the States to overcome this vertical fiscal imbalance or, alternatively, looking at a sharing of taxation powers. While he was Treasurer, it could not occur. When Mr Keating was gone, for a moment or two both the Prime Minister and Mr Kerin had the courage to advance it. Then Mr Keating came out and made it part of the leadership issue. The sequence of events logically followed.

PARA.TAB: Only a few days later Mr Keating again lifted the pain and went on to attack a suggestion that the Prime Minister might adopt Premier Kirner's requirement of a statement on jobs. Mr Keating advanced the heat by saying that what Australia needed, in his view, was an immediate one per cent interest rate cut, an incentive plan to generate new production, more help for long term employment, et cetera. Next we find that the Prime Minister starts to back-pedal, as we have found on so many issues during the term of his leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Old Jellyback.

—Who first raised the expression `Old Jellyback'? Guess who first raised it? It would not surprise honourable senators to be reminded that it was Mr Keating. This leadership contest within the Australian Labor Party is so embarrassing because it encompasses not only members of the organisation, not only members of the back bench, but members of the Cabinet. We saw an example of it again today.

PARA.TAB: Three times Senator Button was given the opportunity to say, `I support the Prime Minister', and refused to do so. Senator Richardson was also given the opportunity. Whilst Minister Dawkins and Minister Richardson undermine the Prime Minister and whilst Senator Button is not prepared to stand up and say that he supports the Prime Minister, it is not surprising that the Prime Minister himself does not have the guts to make any positive decisions, because he is on the edge of the end of his reign as leader. The numbers are being counted. You know, Mr Deputy President, that they were being counted again in this place last night. There is no doubt that eventually Mr Keating will wear him down. There is no doubt about that at all. It is a process of exhaustion.

I will tell the Senate why the issue is important. Whilst the Leader of the Government in the Senate got up today and said that he is not prepared to tell the Senate whether the Federal Government now has a position on tax sharing, the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was ringing around State Premiers confirming to them that the Commonwealth has no position—going one step further; in fact withdrawing the communique group that was supposed to meet to draft the communique for the forthcoming Premiers Conference because the Commonwealth's position is changing. Why has the Commonwealth's position changed? It has changed because of the leadership crisis and the paralysis that that has brought upon this Government.

I said the undermining is not only in the organisation, not only in the back bench, but also in the Cabinet, which reminds me of the next event in this unholy sequence of events. That was the former ALP national president and Queensland Deputy Premier, Tom Burns, coming into the act on 3 November. He attacked Mr Keating; he said he was sick of the disloyalty of Mr Keating. What did he say? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal president in my day would have rung him and said: `Mate, you are stepping out of line'.

He would have stopped him. Who is the Federal President of the Labor Party? Senator Loosely. Would he do that? Of course not. He cannot do that. He came out instead defending Mr Keating. He defended the right to comment, saying:
It's the task of the President to make certain that people in the ALP have an opportunity to argue ideas in the forums of the party.

Would he have done that with anyone other than Mr Keating, the person he is supporting to be Prime Minister of this country? What did Senator Richardson come out and say when Burns, one should have thought quite reasonably, was saying that it was time that Mr Keating was brought into line? Senator Richardson, a member of Mr Hawke's Cabinet, said:
If Tommy's said that, Tommy's wrong. Then again, that would not be the first time.
Any form of public dispute can damage the party. Having said that Mr Keating is also of the view that unemployment is damaging the party.

So we had both campaign managers for Mr Keating—a member of Mr Hawke's own Cabinet, Senator Richardson, and the Federal President of the ALP, Senator Loosely—standing up for Keating and in effect saying that he has the right to undermine the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: What happened then, of course, is that this Monday we had the Caucus meeting on new federalism. Prime Minister Hawke was drawn before his own people to explain his ever-changing position on tax sharing. As a result of that, we read in the press—and it has not been disputed—that Mr Hawke backs away from the undertaking he gave to the Premiers at the July conference. He now backs away from the undertaking to give them a new share of taxation.

What is the reaction of the Premiers? The reaction of both Premier Carmen Lawrence from Western Australia and Premier Bannon from South Australia was to condemn him. Carmen Lawrence acknowledges that the issue of new federalism, the sharing of tax, is now linked to the leadership issue. She recognised that that was what forced Prime Minister Hawke to draw back from his previous position. What did Premier Bannon say? He said that, unless the Commonwealth is prepared to return to its previous position and seriously give the opportunity for the States to take these new taxing powers, or at least to share these new taxing powers, the conference might as well not be held at all.

But the battle continues within the Party, leading to the arguments last night over numbers. The ALP senior vice-president, who is on the Left, not surprisingly comes out in support of Mr Hawke and condemns Mr Keating. Then we have the Victorian ALP President, Paul Slape, who says that Mr Keating's rise to prime ministership is `inevitable', putting the pressure back on Mr Hawke. What do we have today? We find that the Prime Minister has moved yet again and is now prepared to look at the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not today.

—The reports today indicate that the Prime Minister has moved yet again and is now prepared to look at the possibility of a tax sharing arrangement with the States. Senator Button is alluding to yesterday when the Prime Minister made that concession in the House of Representatives. He also said, `But there are many difficulties. There are theoretical difficulties and there are practical difficulties', which brings me back to the question that I asked Senator Button today.

PARA.TAB: In effect, Mr Hawke is again giving himself the out. In other words, being pressed now by the Premiers, he changes his position again and says, `Yes, we will look at a sharing of taxes but I give myself the out by saying to the State Premiers that there are many theoretical and practical difficulties'. So it is not surprising that the Premiers are angry. It is not surprising that the Party is angry. Most importantly, it is not surprising that the country is not getting the leadership that it needs at this time of economic crisis; at this time when over one million Australians are unemployed, when major decisions have to be made and when hard decisions have to be made—decisions relating to the structural changes that are necessary to get efficiency back into this country to enable our producers to be competitive again. Prime Minister Hawke cannot make those decisions because he is continually under threat from within the Party, from within the organisation and, as we saw today, from within his own Cabinet.

We condemn that situation. We condemn the fact that the Ministers in here today and the Cabinet are not prepared to stand up for their Prime Minister. Most of all, we condemn the fact that this country is not being given the leadership it deserves at a time of economic crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in very strong support of the motion of my Leader, Senator Hill, before the Senate today. Today in this place I put this simple question to Senator Button: does he condemn Mr Keating for his continuing efforts to overthrow the Prime Minister? Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate—the third most senior Minister—refused to condemn the man whose existence is now devoted wholly and solely to destabilising the Government of which Senator Button is such a senior figure. He refused to condemn the man who is blatantly, openly, deliberately and arrogantly devoting himself to pulling down, to overthrowing, his Prime Minister—the Prime Minister of this nation. Not only though did Senator Button refuse to condemn Mr Keating; even more significantly, he also refused to support the Prime Minister. Not once, not twice but thrice did he refuse our offer to support his own Prime Minister.
—Did the cock crow?

—Yes, then the cock crowed. What happened was that another fighting cock of this place, one of the heroes of the Government, Senator Richardson, was given the same opportunity. What did Senator Richardson do? He ducked and ran for cover. He refused to support his Prime Minister. And no wonder! When one looks at the turmoil that is taking place within this Government, when one looks at the continual destabilising attempts to undermine the leadership of this country, when one finds that that results in a total policy paralysis—the greatest example, but by no means the only example, being the bringing on of the greatest recession that this country has had in 60 years—when one knows all of those things are happening and that the numbers are being counted again, it is perhaps no wonder that the senior figures of this Government run for cover. They might cover for themselves, but what are they doing to this country? They are leaving this country leaderless and destabilised. One million people are on the unemployment scrap heap as a result and more are going there day by day. What this Government is doing to this country is an absolute disgrace.

PARA.TAB: It is no wonder that the President of the United States today cancelled his visit to Australia; it is no wonder that he has said that he is not coming here. Why is he not coming here? I bet that one of the main reasons he is not coming is that his advisers have said to him that, based on the intelligence coming out of Australia, it is unwise to come here at a time when the Government is so unstable and the leadership is so undermined.

The cancellation of the visit clears a very important hurdle in Paul Keating's move towards the prime ministership—it gives him that extra month. All the numbers, of course, and the attempts for the next leadership coup would have had to take account of the Bush visit taking place. The Bush visit is not taking place now and I bet the bookies will be out. Senator Schacht is listening with some interest. I ask him: what is the favoured time now for the next coup? Poor old Senator Evans; I hope he picks up the peace prize before Senate Schacht moves in.

The other reason that President Bush is not coming is that he was shown the itinerary and it said, `With Prime Minister—to be advised'. He had to be advised which Prime Minister he was going to be with.
Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —We can all laugh about those things but it is a tragedy. It is a tragedy for this country; it is a tragedy for every Australian, particularly the million plus who are either out of work or underemployed; and it is a tragedy for those families of Australia who believed at one stage that they could trust government to look after them and be interested in them, their responsibilities and their future. They are the people who have been let down by this Government; they are the people who have been let down by the continual undermining and destabilising within the Government's own ranks; and they are the people who have been let down by this Government, by this Labor Party, spending its whole time concentrating on its internal brawling simply because two egomaniac sized men cannot settle their personal differences and their ambitions. That is a disgrace. Every Australian knows that it is a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: In the last two days it has led to the jettisoning of what should have been the most important reform in Australia's Federal history in terms of a reshaping of Federal-State relations. It was a reshaping that the Prime Minister launched with great bravado in July of last year—only 16 months ago. He announced—and we welcomed—a series of Special Premiers Conferences to reshape this nation and the relationship between the Commonwealth and State governments.

It was a reshaping that looked as though it was going fairly well, until 23 October. What happened on 23 October? Paul Keating got up and made a speech saying that he did not like what was happening. What happened? Within 10 days this Government completely reversed thrust on what it had been saying was the move towards the most important reform in Federal-State relations in our history. Every Australian will suffer grievously from that absolute back flip, that absolute 180 degrees turnaround by the Government.

Not only has the Government done that, but it has further exposed just how little people can believe what the Prime Minister says, even in this Parliament. Yesterday in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister said that he did not know of any proposals by the States to have income tax sharing arrangements of any description, or any hand back of income taxing powers to the States, to be put forward at the Perth Special Premiers Conference at the end of this month. We know that that is not true.

The Premiers met last week in Adelaide and virtually agreed on a piece of paper which sets out those proposals in detail. The Prime Minister has been advised; he knows the content of that paper. Indeed, Premiers Bannon and Greiner have an arrangement to meet the Prime Minister this Friday after the EPAC meeting to formally give him the paper that he informally knows the content of already. That paper includes unanimous, specific proposals for handing back to the States a share of the income taxing powers of this nation, with an initial proposal that it be 6 per cent. That would bring to the States a measure of revenue of approximately $10 billion, which would go an enormous way to correcting the so-called vertical fiscal imbalance, the mishmash between expenditure and revenue responsibilities, as between the Commonwealth and the States. It is known and universally accepted as one of the major problems in achieving efficient government and efficient division of responsibilities in this nation.

Yesterday the Prime Minister said that he did not know anything about that at all. That—I have to be careful not to be unparliamentary—is not the truth. Today in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister refused again to acknowledge any knowledge of that. The point is that this continual misleading—deliberately or otherwise—of the Australian people, this continual dissembling to the Australian people, is due to a lack of leadership in this nation. It is due to great destructive, vicious divisions within the Government, which are leading to a total policy paralysis. Every Australian suffers as a result.

I have tried in this place over the last year or more to get one sensible, serious answer out of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) on matters pertaining to the economy. I do not think it is an exaggeration to say that on not one occasion has Senator Button or the Government treated those questions seriously. Not just I, but my colleagues on this side, have asked very serious questions about the state of the nation, the state of the economy, the state of all the other areas of concern in this nation. With very few exceptions, do we ever get a serious attempt by the Government to address those issues?

That is one of the important reasons behind Senator Hill's motion today. I believe that the Australian people deserve better than that. I believe that the Australian people want a government that will be honest with them; that will level with them; that will give them the facts; that will give them the truth; and that will give them some hope for the future. This Government, very sadly, does none of those things. It is a disgrace. The Government deserves to be condemned in the roundest possible terms. For that reason, I support Senator Hill's motion today very strongly indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, Senator Fudd is behaving very badly indeed in this respect. He should observe the decencies of this place and refer to us by our proper titles.

—In the context of a debate on whether the Australian Labor Party supports its Prime Minister, Senator Evans, who is the great peacemaker of the world, gets up. PARA.TAB: Senator Hill couched this motion in terms of new federalism because this is the issue which has highlighted the paralysis that exists in the Government. `Vertical fiscal imbalance' is that wonderful phrase which has become synonymous with the imbalance which exists between the Federal and State governments. Remedial treatment is needed to allow a better and more efficient working relationship between the Commonwealth and the State governments. But the Prime Minister's one step forward and two steps backward approach to the agenda for new federalism simply has shown that he succumbs, on a daily basis, to the pressure that is being applied by Mr Keating.

Senator Button delivered and anointed Mr Hawke in 1983. He took the leadership away from Bill Hayden and gave it to Bob Hawke in 1983 in a celebrated expedition he made to Brisbane, having nurtured and carried the votes and delivered them in Brisbane. Today, given the opportunity to support the man Senator Button personally anointed, he denied his own leader thrice. He denied him as Peter denied three times when the cock crowed. One could say that Senator Loosley wants to play the role of Pontius Pilate, because it was Senator Loosley who said, when commenting on Mr Burns's comments, `We have now passed on since then'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who would listen to you?

—It is very interesting that Senator Faulkner is anxious to interject, but it is also most interesting that Senator Faulkner is not prepared to get up and defend his own Prime Minister, whom he is supposed to support. Perhaps he is going to surprise us all by rising to speak when I finish speaking. Perhaps he has had to send out for reinforcements, for a man of more courage. I will be most interested to see whether he stands to support his own leader. I will be interested to see whether he has the courage to do that.
—I will have a few bob on it with you.

—My colleague here is prepared to put money on it, to take a wager. Perhaps we could find someone who might be prepared to be a stakeholder. We have simply reached the stage where we have a paralysis of policy which is resulting in this country being ungoverned.

PARA.TAB: As well as Senator Button's attitude—that he would not support the Prime Minister whom he personally anointed in 1983—the opportunity was given to Senator Richardson to stand up and say something in favour of his Government's leader, the Prime Minister. But he chose not to do so; he chose to accept your ruling, Mr Deputy President, that it was not pertinent to his portfolio and therefore he could duck it. In fact, Mr Deputy President, if you have a good look at the Standing Orders, at page 42 you will see that during Question Time questions may be put to Ministers relating to public affairs. I would have thought that the question of whether or not the Prime Minister is being undermined by his former Treasurer is very much a question of public affairs and one which is directly pertinent to the way in which this country is being governed—or, rather, not being governed.

I think Senator Evans is about to leave the chamber. But he has been replaced, so currently there are still only three members of the Government who are prepared to even listen to the debates which affect their Prime Minister. Senator Evans referred to intellectual and moral paralysis; indeed, it is a very good description of his own side of the chamber, where we have Government members who denigrate the office of the Prime Minister by refusing to support their own Prime Minister. We have seen today the cancellation of a visit by President Bush, having literally come to the stage where any good results that flowed from the cooperation between the United States and Australia during the Gulf war have been undermined by the selfish action of Mr Keating in undermining the Prime Minister.

Of course, the problem is that there are those who are aiding and abetting the undermining; there are those who refuse to stand up and support the man who is allegedly the head of the Government and who is running the country. Wise words they were indeed when the Labor Party said during the last election, `If you can't govern yourself you can't govern the country'. How those words have become prophetic and have come back to haunt this ailing, waning, disintegrating Labor Government!

Senator Hill's motion is one that we support—and I support—very strongly. Senator Hill has drawn attention to the fact that, given the opportunity, a senior Minister—namely, the one who represents the Prime Minister in this place—denied his own Prime Minister on three separate occasions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the report entitled Women & TAFE—A National Plan of Action, I point out that the issues affecting women's training and participation in the work force need to be addressed within award restructuring and workplace reorganisation. As the report says, women continue to experience disadvantage in the labour market. They make up some 41.6 per cent of the work force; 39.5 per cent of women workers have part time jobs which are often casual. They are concentrated in a small number of occupations at the bottom of the employment hierarchy. This is reflected in the pattern of women's participation in TAFE. PARA.TAB: Like a lot of materials that come from this Government, it is a pretty glossy sort of document. It is very shiny and very expensive. It is very easy to produce documents like this when someone else's money is being spent. It is 40 pages in length.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is user friendly.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at a section entitled `Support for Women in TAFE'. That is all about child-care, counselling and support services. It covers two full pages but says almost nothing. I also draw the Senate's attention to the funding of child-care and the child-care funds provision under the JET scheme, which is being used by many women undertaking TAFE courses who are sole parents. Representatives from the scheme told the Senate Estimates Committee that there was no demand, yet sole parents tell me that they are being turned back from access to child-care under the JET scheme because there is no money. Not a mention.

—The State governments are in difficulties thanks to the economic mismanagement of this Federal Government. Ask Mrs Kirner about her problems with public transport. Ask Mrs Kirner. What is she doing? She puts up the fees and people cannot afford her public transport.

We have to do better. This glossy document is long on rhetoric and very short on performance. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Crowley, the Chairman of Estimates Committee C, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee C.
—On behalf of Senator Cooney, the Chairman of Estimates Committee E, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee E.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—The Committee is considering the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee E—the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services—and had reached program 6.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer provided to Estimates Committee E in response to a question placed on notice by Senator Short. In the last year the Health Insurance Commission undertook two research studies which I am particularly interested in: one was into community attitudes to Medicare; and the other, pharmacists' attitudes towards the Health Insurance Commission. I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer to advise me of the reason for commissioning this survey into pharmacists' attitudes towards the Health Insurance Commission; what were the key findings or results of this survey; and what changes or outcomes have resulted from this report?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the survey was essentially attempting to assess the satisfaction of the clients—with the pharmacists as the clients—with the service they were receiving. As there was at that time some element of dispute in the area of pharmacy, there was a mixed response. In terms of changed outcomes, the responses indicated a desire for enhanced communication from the Health Insurance Commission and I understand that a regular bulletin to pharmacists has been initiated as a consequence.
—Basically, the only change that has occurred is a regular bulletin. Is that right?

—If Senator Patterson wants someone to examine the minute detail to see whether there is some other change, I am happy for that to happen, but my advice is that it was essentially an assessment of whether the clients were satisfied, the clients indicated a desire for enhanced communication and that is what took place.
—Would it be possible for the Committee to have a copy of the findings of that survey?
—As far as I can tell at this stage there is no problem with that.

—The survey of community attitudes towards Medicare cost $92,500. I believe that a number of members of the Committee would be interested in seeing the results of that survey. I ask that that be treated in the same way and that members of the Committee be provided with the results of the survey of attitudes to Medicare.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers advise me that they thought that, at the very least, an executive summary had been provided but, if that is not the case, it will be done.

—I understand that the Health Insurance Commission has reached an agreement with the software suppliers to expand—I think it is to double—the size of the data that is transmitted electronically from pharmacies to the Health Insurance Commission. Is this correct?
—Are you asking whether extra computer capacity had been acquired in order to carry out a greater workload in relation to certain data?
—That is right.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that no further capacity is required, that there is sufficient within the system, and that the data that is being sought to be transmitted relates to repeat prescriptions.

—I am sorry, I was not asking about capacity, I was asking about the data. My question was: I believe that the Health Insurance Commission has reached an agreement with the software suppliers to expand the size of data that is transmitted electronically—not the capacity—from the pharmacies to the Health Insurance Commission.
—As I understand it, the extra data relates to prescriber numbers and the number of repeat prescriptions. That is what this software change seeks to do.
—So it is only those two areas; there is nothing else at all?
—The officers cannot inform me of anything further at the moment. We are not trying to evade the issue but they are the two that come to the officers' minds as being the principal reasons.

—Could the Minister tell me whether any agreement was reached between the individual pharmacies or organisations representing them about the type of information that might be required in this additional data?

—I understand that the Guild certainly was present at the relevant meeting. The officers' understanding is that the Guild was in agreement. We have not had any communication back from the Guild but the officers' impression was that the Guild was not opposed to the suggestion.
—As the Minister knows, the Guild represents only a percentage of the pharmacists. Were the other pharmacists included in those negotiations or discussions?

—I understand that they were not. The Guild was the only body present in a representative capacity. It is true that it does not have a membership embracing all pharmacists throughout Australia, but I understand that it is a fairly large proportion—it may be as much as 70 per cent. One of the difficulties when one is trying to attain a policy position is that one has to deal with a body which at least holds itself out to be and is recognised by a substantial number of professional people as representing interests in most negotiations with the Federal Government.

—I understand the problem but when over 30 per cent of the pharmacies are not members of the Guild it presents problems for them, as the Minister will be aware. Will any costs be incurred by pharmacies in collecting this new data?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the sort of software changes that need to be undertaken can be incorporated and achieved in the normal process by which the software company from time to time updates and changes its software. An indication was given that if the pharmacists wish to approach the Government for any discussions on these matters, the Government would be open to discussions.

—Obviously the matter has not yet been finalised. If the Minister has not heard back from the Guild, if the pharmacies were invited to open negotiations with the Government on any of the problems that they could see as a result, when would the extra data collection start?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I may have given a wrong impression to the chamber. The discussions that took place were with the software company, which was to come back to the Government as to the costs of carrying out the software changes. It is intended that these changes come into place on 1 February next year, and that date is being aimed for. If the software company incorporates these changes in the normal way in which it updates the programs, there is no problem. If there is a problem, we can discuss the question of the cost of updating or changing the programs with the Government. In other words, the cost burden of the change will be borne by the software company rather than by the pharmacists.

—It has been put to me that some pharmacies will be forced to upgrade their computer equipment to 386 standard to enable them to be able to meet the new requirements. If this is so, will the Health Insurance Commission be offering financial assistance for those pharmacies in the upgrading. Will it cover the additional cost?

—I am told that the pharmacists already have this sort of information in their systems. This software program will enable the software companies to better extract that information and transmit it to the Department.
—So the Minister can give me a guarantee that there will be no extra cost to the pharmacies; is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage all I am prepared to say is that I understand the costs of this exercise will relate to the software company itself rather than to the pharmacist. I am not sure of the relationship between the software company and the pharmacist which may lead to the software company trying to pass on some costs that it bears to individual pharmacists. I am sure that the Guild and others can acquaint us with those matters if something needs to be further followed up, and it will be.

—I ask again: will the Government pay for those costs if there is a need to upgrade? After all, it is to suit the requirements of the Government not the pharmacists that the pharmacy may have to incur these extra costs. Will the Government be financing them?

—I understand the argument that Senator Walters is putting. All I am saying is that until we have a better understanding of the real incidence and where the costs are really to be borne, it would be premature for me to give an undertaking on the part of the Government.
—I can understand the Minister's caution, but it seems to me quite extraordinary that the pharmacists will be asked once again to foot the bill.
—If it is true. I am saying that we will find out.

—Very well, if it is true. But the Minister cannot even give me a guarantee. When I ask the Minister whether it is true, he says that he cannot tell me whether they have to incur extra costs. I feel it is extraordinary that he would suggest that it may be right that the pharmacists have to put in extra costs.
—I did not say that. Don't put words in my mouth!

—Well, the Minister cannot give me a guarantee. I have also been led to understand that a number of new fields are to be created in this expansion. I know that there are two areas and I would like the Minister to clarify them. They include name, previous suppliers, authority number, and the emergency supply unique patent ID. Is it correct that these are the additional extended data?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that no new data is being asked to be collected by the pharmacists, but the way in which it is transmitted and extracted is to be varied.
—There is an authority number. Could the Minister tell me what that number is?
—Certain prescriptions have to have authorisation and this is a number that refers to that prime authority.
—Is that new? What is the authority number? Is it the dispensary number? Is it the prescription form number? What is it? I do not understand it.
—The officer advising me believes it to be the prescription number. If we can get better advice on this matter, we will, but that is his understanding.
—I read from the document that new fields have been added. It gives the data in existing fields and then gives the data in the new fields.
—Senator, we did not know that this was coming up so we do not have the very precise information that you require. It is very hard in the Committee of the Whole to deal with this.
—Well, Minister, it has only just landed on my desk too, and I was not aware—
—Had the honourable senator told us before lunch we could have acted on it.

—I was not aware, of course, that this sort of thing was even contemplated by the Government, and therefore I would have thought that we would possibly have had some information about it. If one of the senior officers present who has been at the negotiations cannot tell me what the new fields are, relating to previous suppliers, authority number, emergency supplies, unique patent ID, which are all new and not from the original data that is being processed at the moment, perhaps the Minister could take this question on notice and provide me with a run down of exactly what is required, what is new and what is not.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly give that undertaking, but for the benefit of the hundreds of thousands of people listening to this broadcast I think I should indicate that it is normal practice in the Committee of the Whole to have some notice, and there is a referral system, to enable us to be somewhat prepared. We have been taken a little by surprise and, whilst the officer is doing his best to recall the details of the meeting, he cannot recall every detail. In so far as the honourable senator requires further particulars, I will certainly provide them, on notice.

—I understand that. I certainly did not intend to take the Minister by surprise. In fact, I was taken by surprise when I found out, not from the Government but from other sources, that this extension was on, and I thought that the officers would have had the information that I am asking for. However, I understand that that information is not available and that the Minister will supply me with it later. On 19 September we discussed the CPI increases in the Medicare schedule during Estimates Committee proceedings. Has the Department conducted any studies to determine the costs associated with the operation of doctors' practices?
—The most recent study of which we are aware was undertaken in 1983 by the Australian Medical Association.
—So the answer to that is no. Is there any government model that could be used to give an approximate guide as to public GP services in any of the States or the Territories?

—I understand that there is a medical fees index, which has been based on the original study undertaken in 1982-83, and that the Australian Bureau of Statistics has been approached in order to update the weighting, I think was the expression used, of those various components of the fee structure.

—It seems inappropriate to me, and I am sure it does to the Minister, too, that that model should go back eight years. The cost of general practices would have changed in that period, as I am sure the Minister would acknowledge. Has the Department had any discussions with the AMA or the RACGP relating to GP practice costs recently?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The standing review group has raised the question. However, as I understand it, no study has been undertaken. That is all I know at the moment. (Quorum formed) I believe that the Department has indicated to the AMA and to the Royal College that it is willing to undertake a relative value study across the whole schedule and it is awaiting a response from the AMA. I am told that the AMA is itself independently conducting an update of its 1982-83 survey.
—I have some detailed questions, but I did give the Department notice that I would be asking detailed questions on Budget Related Paper No. 9, which deals with health care in Australia.
—We did not get the questions; we just got a general statement through a phone call that the honourable senator was going to ask questions on Budget Related Paper No. 9.
—Yes, therefore I asked for officers who could give me the detail.
—We will try.
—Well, I did give notice as you have requested; the Minister said that it would expedite things if I did.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should make it clear that the area in relation to which Senator Walters, either personally or through the office, indicated that she wanted to ask questions covers the whole of the Medicare arrangements. One could not say that that narrows the field. However, we will do our best to answer what appears to be a list of very particular questions. We will strive to answer each one in detail, if it is a detailed question, but I do not want to give any impression that we have been given notice of the questions.

—I certainly did not intend to give that impression. I did not give notice of the question to the Minister. I asked for the officers who could give details of the questions I will put to the Minister.

PARA.TAB: Budget Related Paper No. 9, Health Care in Australia, sets out five priorities for this and next financial year which are causing some concern. The first proposal is the development of practice grants to complement fee for service reimbursement. A ministerial press release dated 10 October 1991—and hence after Estimates—announced that the implementation of this proposal would be brought forward to commence as soon as possible, at a cost of up to $12m. Can the Minister say how many demonstration practice grants the Commonwealth expects to approve and where the Government is expecting they will be established?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there is no fixed figure in view. Discussions are to be undertaken with the professional bodies which will lead to a clearer idea of the numbers to be funded. After those discussions, there will be a series of advertisements calling for applications. It will then be in response to those applications and the criteria established in the discussions that a number of practice grants will be set up.
—I thank the Minister. Could the Minister explain in some detail what is to be expected of a practice for it to be eligible to receive a practice grant?

—As I understand it, the discussions that I have indicated are to take place with professional bodies are designed to clarify which services will qualify for funding, using a type of exemplary practice, if you like, and any additional services that might be provided.

PARA.TAB: In general, a practice grant would provide some remuneration to those general practices which choose to reduce their reliance on fee for service. It would take the form of regular block payments not linked directly to the number of services provided. It is believed that this would better target health benefits since it would offer appropriate financial incentives for practices to engage in best practice care, provide financing arrangements to encourage better integration of the health system, and involve GPs in a wider range of activities. These could be funded through a trade-off between providing funds for practice grants and providing funds for schedule fee increases for GP services. That is the idea. However, it is at a very basic stage at the moment and is subject to discussions with the professional bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do not understand that. Can the Minister explain that to me? I do not know whether, as a general practitioner, it means that one does not charge anyone; one gets a grant from the Government; there is no fee for service. Does one bulkbill only; does one receive a grant from the Government because one is bulkbilling only? Can the Minister explain to me what he just said?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not intended to displace the present Medicare arrangements in a holus bolus way. What is indicated, as I did say in my opening sentence, is that there will be a system of remuneration to those general practices which choose to reduce their reliance on fee for service. There would be regular block payments which would not be directly linked to the number of services provided. There could be a core practice grant which would supplement the fee for service income of the practice. It is thought that would reduce the pressure to perhaps provide an inappropriate form of GP consultation service involving the temptation to rapid throughputs of patients, clients or persons calling on the GP. It could also be that another range of practice grants could be available to provide incentives for desirable activities such as health promotion and prevention, immunisation, provision of allied health services, such as physiotherapy and nursing, or to target areas of special need, for example, rural areas, services for Aboriginals, palliative care, geriatric care and so on.

PARA.TAB: The major point is that these are only indications of the sorts of matters which will be raised with the professional bodies and they are the ones, in consultation with the Government and in discussions and negotiations with the Government, who will lead us to a situation where the ideas, which are only broadly sketched out there, can be refined and made to work practically.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Mr Howe is wanting is for a certain number or a certain percentage of general practices in each State to be given a grant by the Government for bulkbilling a certain percentage of the patients. That grant will be then be greater than if a general practitioner bulkbilled individual patients. This would be done in the hope that the general practitioner, because of his bulkbilling, would not be financially disadvantaged and therefore could put through fewer patients than he would otherwise feel pressured to do for financial reasons. As I understand what the Minister said in relation to that particular area, a block grant given to that GP to bulkbill or to have a service which is not a fee for service for patients would not financially benefit the GP over and above what it would if he were conducting a bulkbilling for a lesser number of patients. Is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The latter part of the middle part of the honourable senator's comments was correct, I believe, in so far as one was talking about a block grant which would reduce the reliance of the practice on fee for service. I do not know that I ever mentioned bulkbilling as being what was sought to be displaced: it could be some other form of billing. However, fee for service was not to be the sole revenue generating mechanism in the GP's practice concerned, and the block grant or some formula like that would cover a payment simply not directly linked to the number of services provided.

PARA.TAB: I do not think I said either that the amount of the block grant, if that is the way to put it, would be pitched at a level greater than might otherwise be earned through the fee for service system. It may be exactly the same. The point is to try to get a different model of payment to the general practice to see whether the types of consultations undertaken, without the pressure of the fee for service problem, lead to a better provision of health care for the persons who attend the particular practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister tell me the difference between a block grant and a wage under those circumstances?

—I do not know what the next question will be. I do not know quite where the constitutional limits might lie. I am completely vague about all this. However, if one is talking about a payment to a practice, one is not simply talking about wages. One is talking about all of the costs associated with the provision of the medical service from a particular premise, including lighting, heating, the physical requirements of waiting rooms and consulting rooms, et cetera. I suppose the grant would not simply be directed to remunerating the individual general practitioner in the sense of being, say, a monthly wage; rather, it would be an amount of money which would help defray the costs of the practice, including remuneration to the medical practitioner.

—A wage would do that anyway. A general practitioner could not be expected to pay for the costs associated with seeing patients. Naturally, the wage would include electricity and all the associated costs of the practice. It would seem to me that this is very clearly a step to socialising as many doctors as are willing to accept a grant. If a grant—or a wage, under any other name; we can call it whatever we like—is made, in the end the Government, not the patient, will be paying the doctor. When we get down to the nitty-gritty of this proposal, we find that the Government's philosophy has always been to socialise as many doctors as possible. I would be very grateful if the Minister could attempt to convince me that this is not a very large step along these lines.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only emphasise that I do not see it as a wage. There is no contract of employment between the Government and the medical practitioner concerned. A payment will be made to the practice to defray all the costs of the practice. A portion would be a remuneration of the general practitioner concerned. It is not equivalent to a wage in the sense that, if it were, the GP would have to pay personal income tax in respect of the whole grant and then pay for the electricity and everything else out of what was left after the Commissioner of Taxation got his share. As I understand it, it is not meant to operate like that. It is a grant to the practice to cover all of its expenses. Therefore, it does not really bear a relationship to the idea of a wage.
—The Minister is not suggesting for one moment that that grant would not be included in the GP's tax liability?

—If one sets up a practice and tries to work out the income and the expenditures in relation to payment for electricity and heating, the provision of equipment and all the rest of it, one would take a completely different approach from that one would take if those things were being paid out of one's wage. That is the point that I am making.

—The term `demonstration' is used in respect of the early stages of this initiative. What does `demonstration' mean in this case? Is it a trial, an example, a pilot scheme or something like that? What is the ultimate aim of the initiative?

—I suppose that all those words could be somewhat analogous. The idea is to establish a different model for the provision of general practice in the community and thereby demonstrate to other GPs and to the general community how this alternative might operate.

—Is the long term aim to have all GPs being paid practice grants as a subsidy in return for reduced fees for the service offered, or will only a percentage of doctors be included in the scheme? If that is the case, what percentage will that be and how will the doctors be selected?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The aim is to provide better health care for Australians, particularly in this primary area of contact with their GPs. If the demonstration program reveals that this initiative does not assist in the provision of better health care, I imagine it would be scrapped.
—The Minister did not answer my question. Is the aim to have all GPs under this scheme?
—I told Senator Walters what the aim was.
—All GPs or just a percentage?

—I did not admit to Senator Walters's form of question. I said that the aim is to provide better health care for all Australians. If these demonstration projects do not provide evidence that that benefit flows to the community, it will not be a question of a percentage or all—it will be a question of none.
—The second proposal announced under this heading refers to a system of practice budgets. What is the purpose of practice budgets?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that under the arrangement a budget is allocated to general practices to cover the cost of diagnostic services and pharmaceuticals. This could build on the Government's other reforms in the pharmaceutical, pathology and radiology areas. It could also facilitate the trade-offs which GPs make between different approaches to the care of their patients that support the role of the GP as a coordinator of a network of care.
—The Minister can imagine what my next question will be. Is the budget designed to limit the number and types of tests that doctors should order for their patients?

—I am told that the question of reaching a limit beyond which a doctor cannot order tests has not been finally determined. It is one of the exact matters which is the subject of discussion with the professional bodies. This is the correct way in which the negotiations leading to a proper outcome should proceed.

—As the Minister could well imagine, if one is given a budget, very clearly it is anticipated that one will not go beyond that budget. One of the prime responsibilities of government is to make sure that the budget is not exceeded. The Minister is now telling me that a decision has not been made as to whether a doctor would be able to exceed the budget. If that is the case, why on earth use the word `budget'?

—I am advised that there will not be an absolutely single model for these practice budgets. There will be various budgets which will deal precisely with the borderline of reaching the limits of the type that Senator Walters indicated. The different ways in which the practice budget might be provided is one of the matters which will be discussed with the profession.

—It seems that there has been very little thinking through of these reforms for general practice if the Minister cannot give me that sort of detail or if he says, `Whether he exceeds his budget or whether that budget will be limiting is a matter to be discussed'. I do not know what is such a budget. My understanding of the word `budget' is some special figure or cost that is not to be exceeded. But if the Minister tells me that all has to be discussed and the word `budget' will not necessarily be used in the way that it is generally understood, then I suppose I will have to wait for the discussions to take place.

PARA.TAB: I am sure every general practitioner would want to know what happens if a doctor reaches the end of his budget. Does that mean he cannot have any additional diagnostic costs or services that would exceed that budget? The third proposal in Budget Related Paper No. 9 deals with the accreditation of general practices. Will the Minister explain that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The accreditation of general practices is seen by the Government as a natural development of the vocational registration arrangements. Those arrangements are a form of accreditation but of individual practitioners. Accreditation would be a matter for the profession but it could provide a framework within which many steps could be taken to address quality of care issues in general practice. In other words, it is building on the individual vocational registration arrangements.

—Mr Howe has already said that an individual practice would not get an accreditation but the Department requires that a limit of three or four, preferably more, general practitioners should get together with paramedical services attached. That sort of practice would get accreditation and his wishes. Could the Minister go into that for me? This is the explanation I am wanting and I am finding it very hard to drag out of Senator Tate the intention of the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that accreditation will be a matter for the profession and the criteria that it develops on what should enable accreditation will be a matter for its endeavour to formulate rather than the Department. The accreditation process will be undertaken fully with the relevant professional bodies.
—Have any discussions taken place with the AMA, the Royal Australasian College of General Practitioners or any of the medical associations?
—The Minister met with the President of the AMA and the College of General Practitioners on 17 October. Since then there have been two meetings with both organisations.
—What was the outcome of those meetings?

—At the moment there have only been two meetings on getting to know the scope of the project facing those engaged in these discussions. There was general agreement between the Minister and the AMA and the RACGP. That resulted in a general agreement that the major issues facing general practice are: the oversupply and maldistribution of general practitioners, which leaves excess numbers in urban areas and a shortage in rural areas; concerns about quality of care; and the importance of linking financial incentives to the provision of high quality care in a way that ensures that doctors providing high quality care receive appropriate levels of remuneration. Those issues are the very ones which the negotiations I have indicated are designed to address.
—So accreditation did not take place but some of the other issues that I am coming to and which I have discussed with the Minister did take place?
—The discussion about accreditation will be a proper part of the discussions, which are now being undertaken as a result of the meeting between Mr Howe, Dr Shepherd and Dr Bahugiar.

—We have spoken a lot about the oversupply of general practitioners. Yet the Government made a recent announcement about a scheme to allow the restricted registration of foreign qualified doctors. How will this proposal help solve the alleged problem of the oversupply of doctors referred to in Budget Related Paper No. 9?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the composition of the force of medical practitioners available in the Australian community is a matter which revolves around the question of numbers and social justice in relation to those medical practitioners who receive their training overseas and who are in, or available to serve, the Australian community. So there are quite a few matters which need to be taken into account in relation to the oversupply, which is at least agreed to be considerable. Agreement on that between the Minister, the AMA and the RACGP at least provides a very firm foundation for levels of discussion to take place, which I hope would enable the increasing oversupply of GPs to be dealt with effectively.

—The Minister refers to social justice. Is the Minister telling me that it is social justice either to let in or allow the restricted registration of foreign qualified doctors but to cut our own student numbers and stop them from entering medical school? Does the Minister call that social justice?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a question of looking at the oversupply and the maldistribution of doctors in Australia which has many facets. One is, of course, the question of medical immigration, which Senator Walters is looking to emphasise. The output of medical schools is also an important matter. The distribution is already known to be grossly out of proportion in relation to rural areas.

PARA.TAB: The Government is undertaking an examination of the actions other countries have taken to deal with excessive medical immigration through highly restrictive immigration policies. The Government is looking—I do not say with a view to adopting but certainly examining—at measures introduced by other countries. This includes: restrictive quotas on the numbers of overseas trained doctors eligible for rights of medical practice; overall restriction on provider billing numbers, as is done in Canada; and rigorous examinations and internships, as in the USA. There is exclusion of most overseas trained doctors from obtaining general practitioner medical registration or becoming principals in the national health service in the UK.

There are various models by which other countries have attempted to deal with this question. The Government is aware of the need to adopt an approach that in the end achieves the overall and major goal, which is to reduce the problem of oversupply and maldistribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howe has already threatened the AMA with the registration of foreign qualified doctors. It seems to me a most inappropriate way to try to negotiate with the AMA—but that is Mr Howe's method. For the Minister to say that the Government is looking at the social justice side of allowing in foreign doctors while cutting our medical schools seems to be an unbelievable statement.

PARA.TAB: The Minister claims that there is an oversupply of doctors. What is the basis of the claim? Is it based on doctor-patient ratios in other countries? If so, which are the countries? Have any allowances been made to compensate for the necessary differences in doctor-patient ratios between remote, country, urban and metropolitan regions, bearing in mind that we are a very big country with isolated areas?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Budget Paper No. 9 indicates that some estimates would have it that there is an oversupply of nearly 6,000 GPs throughout Australia—5,700 in urban areas and 200 in non-urban areas. This figure was based on doctor-patient ratios of urban 1 : 1,600, non-urban 1 : 1,350. Using these ratios, Australia would currently require 11,100 full time GPs.

PARA.TAB: However, it was estimated that in 1991-92 there will be just under 14,000 full time equivalent GPs. In fact, there are over 24,000 practitioners, taking into account those working part time in private general practice. The indicative oversupply was therefore estimated to be around 26 per cent, or 2,900 full time equivalents—that is, approximately 6,000 doctors when recognising the current proportions of full time and part time GPs. That analysis is being looked at in the consultations that I have indicated are going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister did not answer my question. I asked to which other countries the ratios the Government uses apply. The Government does not pick a figure off the top of its head. Does it say that the ratio in the UK or the USA, for instance, seemed appropriate? Where does the Government get its ratios from?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that in the United Kingdom the figure used is 1 : 1,800. In New South Wales it is 1 : 1,600, for its planning purposes. I have a report of the Illawarra Area Health Service on the Kiama-Shellharbour health planning study of February 1988. On page 160, under the heading `General Practitioners', the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The adequacy of general practice services to this population can be very roughly evaluated by using the guideline of one general practitioner to every 1,600 persons.
That ratio was used in application to the areas under discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who says that is the appropriate figure?
—I don't know.

—The Minister should know. Heavens above! I am asking the Minister what the Government considers is the correct ratio. He tells me that he has picked up the ratio of 1 : 1,600, and then tells me that a little spot in New South Wales says that that is what it thinks is the right ratio. Then he says that in the UK the ratio is 1 : 1,800. Good heavens! The United Kingdom is a very small, densely populated country; Australia is the opposite. How could we even contemplate comparing those two ratios? The Minister then picks a little town in New South Wales and says that someone there has come up with the ratio of 1 : 1,600. Is this the sort of planning that the Government is doing with its health scheme?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it very clear that I was answering Senator Walters's question with respect to what other jurisdictions there are and where the ratio might have been derived.
—I asked for the basis of the claim.

—That is right, exactly. I replied in terms of the United Kingdom and New South Wales. It was applied in this study, but that is the figure used in New South Wales. I am not in a position to say exactly how New South Wales planning authorities, in the provision of health services, arrived at that figure. I suppose it would be possible to ask the New South Wales authorities how they arrived at the figure. I am saying that it is not an unreasonable, plucked-out-of-the air figure, which is what Senator Walters asked me to agree to, in the absence of finding some comparable countries or jurisdictions where a ratio such as this was used. I have found those examples and given them to Senator Walters. I have further indicated, nevertheless, that these are not set in absolute terms. They will be precisely the subject of discussions with the AMA and the royal college. As I understand it, both organisations have agreed that there is an oversupply. The exact quantification of the oversupply is something that needs to be further worked on.

—The Government claims that there is an oversupply of doctors. I asked whether the Minister could tell me the basis of this claim.
