The Minister said that the basis of the claim was 1 : 1,800 in the UK and 1 : 1,600 in New South Wales. When I asked, `Who in New South Wales says that is right?', the Minister said, `How do I know?'. The Government is basing its claim of an oversupply of doctors on someone—he does not know who it is—in New South Wales who said off the top of his head that he thinks 1 : 1,600 ought to be about right.
—That is a complete misdescription of what I said, and you know it.
—I do not believe it is. Even the Minister used the words `off the top of your head'.
—I did not use those words.

—The Minister can look at Hansard tomorrow. I turn to proposal No. 5. The Budget Related Paper says that information technology could substantially enhance diagnostic and patient education roles of GPs, as well as improving the business management of practices. Can the Minister tell me what that means?
—It is in English.
—It is in gobbledegook.
—Senator Walters might think it is; I think it reads very plainly.

—Can the Minister explain to me what information technology could substantially enhance diagnostic and patient education roles of GPs? How can it do that? In what way is it anticipated that it will do it? What is the Government's aim?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a simple statement about the better use of computers in doctors' surgeries to enable them to keep patient records and to enable patients to be recalled for various treatments and so on. It is a fairly straightforward idea. Rather than using card indexes and so on, a doctor's practice may operate more efficiently and be able to gather together information of value in the treatment of the surrounding population who use that particular surgery if certain computer equipment is provided.

—The Minister has told me that this will improve management practices. It would be very nice if we could just wave a magic wand and say to all the general practitioners, `Get your computers in and they will help you improve the business management of your practices'. But the Minister does not say that. The Minister says that the computers will enhance diagnostics. How will they help the doctor diagnose patients and how will they help patient education?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as diagnosis is concerned, if a doctor has a computer with the proper programs, the doctor can enter the various symptoms that are displayed or presented—whatever the terminology is—by the patient. It may be that the doctor will get a range of possibilities which will back up, be of assistance to or supplement the intuitive, physical or face-to-face diagnosis that might be undertaken by the GP. That process seems to me to be very plain and straightforward. I understand that these computer programs are already being used in hospitals. Senator Walters shakes her head. I do not know whether Senator Herron knows about it, but it is a tool that is available to doctors and it can be of great use to them.
—Can you give me the qualification of the person who gave you that reason?
—No, I will not give Senator Walters the qualification.
—I beg your pardon?
—Senator Walters was obviously not listening to my answer.
—I did listen very carefully to the Minister's answer. I asked whether he could give me the qualification of the person who gave him that information.
—No, I will not. I deal with the officers who provide me with information. I will not have them exposed to Senator Walters's analysis of their particular qualifications.
—If the Minister is frightened to give me the qualification of the officer who gave you the answer to that—
—You are being extremely rude!

—I am not being rude. I am far from being rude. I am just saying that I do not believe that the officer who gave the Minister that answer could possibly have had any medical knowledge. If the Minister believes that a doctor can sit at his computer and type up the symptoms that a patient is showing and that that result will end up giving him the ability to diagnose that patient—
—I never said it would.
—You said it would help him.
—That is different.
—Any experienced doctor would never use that sort of system. I have never heard anything quite so fanciful, except in Star Wars. Can the Minister tell me about the patient education roles?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a lot of information on that. I believe that in a modern, technologically advanced practice a patient could enter certain information into a computer and get some very good information back which would be of an educative kind. For example, perhaps one could feed in dietary habits or something like that and get back an indication of one's nutritional deficiencies and needs and the effect on the heart or the blood pressure, or something like that. These are the sorts of things that could be done by tapping into the insatiable appetite to use computers, which we all see when we watch children, rather than what we were brought up on—the booklets and pamphlets—in order to get information about measures one might take to improve one's own health.

—It is no wonder the doctors will need practice grants, if this is the sort of stuff they will have to indulge in. They will certainly need more than practice grants to keep them afloat. Can the Minister tell me the long term aim of this proposal? Will it be possible to transmit data electronically from the general practitioners' surgeries to the Health Insurance Commission? I have been told by the office of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) that that is the case.
—Why are you asking me?
—Because I want it verified. I did not speak to the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The long term aim of the program is to improve the health of Australians by ensuring that they have access to primary care through their general practitioners in a way which serves their health requirements. As to the question of the transmission of data, I do not quite understand whether that is over and above the transmission of data that already occurs, or precisely what Senator Walters is driving at in relation to the core practice grants that we are discussing.
—At the moment, the doctor does not electronically transmit data to the HIC. What does the Minister mean by `over and above the transmission of data that already occurs'?
—I am told that some GPs do transmit claim status.
—That is in relation to bulk billing, is it?
—Yes.

—That is not information. I asked the Minister whether this system was able to transmit data electronically from general practitioners' surgeries to the Health Insurance Commission. His answer was yes.
—No, that was not my answer.
—I am sorry; I thought you said yes. I ask again: is that the long term aim?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The long term aim is as I have described it. The question of the provision of data is something which I am not able to comment on. I have indicated that there is already, in some instances, a provision of data. Whether that is to be supplemented, I am not in a position to answer, in the sense of electronic transmission of data to the HIC.

—Does the Minister mean that the officers do not know the long term aim of the proposal of setting up information technology? As I say, I already have the information from the Minister's office, although I have not spoken to him.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The information technology paragraph or whatever it was that Senator Walters read before related to the technology within the practice to assist the GP and the patient in relation to the provision of health care. It was not, as I understood it, a technology package introduced into the practice to enable the electronic submission of data to the HIC.
—So you are telling me that my information is wrong; is that right?
—I do not know what information Senator Walters has.
—I explained to the Minister that the use of those computers was, in the long term, to transmit information on patient data to the HIC. I am asking whether that is correct.
—I do not know the answer to that question. I do not know the source of Senator Walters's information. I am unable to comment any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Estimates Committee process, I questioned the definition of quality and I asked, `Does that goal include the quality of the care provided?'. The under-secretary said, inter alia, `Yes, it does encompass the idea of appropriate good quality health care'. I said, `The word "quality" is not used throughout the whole report'. The under-secretary said, `I believe it is encompassed in the word "appropriate"'. I had another go, and on this occasion my question was answered by Ms Batman. I said, `But you still do not have anything in place'. Ms Batman replied:

SPEECH.PARA: We do have a monitoring strategy that we can put in place to monitor the impact of the 1 November changes. It is something that we are still working on.

I then asked of Ms Ariotti whether she would define quality. At this stage I began to think, `Perhaps I am wrong; perhaps I do not understand the meaning of the word "quality"'. So I looked it up in the Oxford English Dictionary. `Quality' is defined as `degree of excellence, relative nature or kind or character'. I then looked up the thesaurus and found the words `calibre, distinction, excellence, grade, merit, standing, status, superiority, value or worth'.

PARA.TAB: This afternoon, Senator Tate has talked about governments providing access, and I understand that. The bureaucracy is concerned about delivery. But patients and health care providers are concerned about quality, and that seems to have escaped both government and bureaucracy. There is a fundamental malaise in health care delivery in this nation, whether we like to believe it or not. It does not involve just health care financing: it also involves the quality of the service that is delivered. We have seen the recent changes by the Government in fooling around with decreasing rebates—$2.50 and $3.50. Just imagine the effect that reducing the rebates will have on quality.

I saw in an as yet unpublished paper by two authors of eminence something which encompassed the beliefs I have in relation to general practice in this country. We should bear in mind that general practice is the cornerstone of health care delivery in this nation. Unlike other nations— for example, the United States—we have a far greater number of general practitioners in proportion to specialists than does the United States; so there is no comparison. I quote from this document:

SPEECH.PARA: Life for Australian general practitioners is becoming a succession of professional and clinical contests. Still reeling from the destabilising debates over vocational registration, they now face turbulence over the question of restructuring. Professionally, many doctors feel impotent in a system that does not value their skills, progressively decreases rebates, excludes them from hospitals and leaves them exposed to the competitive pressures exerted by a growing surplus of community-based health professionals. The danger in the current situation is that general practitioners will become so immersed in adversarial conflict that the possibility of real and useful reform of the system will escape from their grasp.

Clinically, many general practitioners feel that the current system is inhibiting the practice of good medicine. Rising community expectations for `quick cures' and the advent of entrepreneurial 24-hour, bulk-billing clinics have ensured that traditional general practice is struggling for its share of the primary medical market. Many general practices are marginally viable at present, and it now seems distinctly possible that the effects of the latest Budget changes will result in the professional demise of significant numbers of general practitioners at the same time as it increases costs to patients.

This leads me to the questions I want to ask, which cover some of the material Senator Walters asked about in relation to practice budgets. It is obvious that there is a design—and it is mentioned in Budget Paper No. 9—and an ongoing process. It is not good enough to say, `We are waiting for discussion with the professionals or the royal colleges'. It is not good enough, if this Government believes that it is planning for the future. One does not plan, produce something, deck it out, and then say, `We are waiting for discussions'. What if the professional bodies—the AMA and the College of General Practitioners—say to the Government, `Get lost; we are not going to discuss it with you'? Does the Government have a fall-back position? Will it impose it on them?

PARA.TAB: This appears to be a government that knows what it is doing—although I doubt that. One only had to see what occurred in relation to the reduction of rebates. That was an absolute debacle, which is continuing and is fuelling the debate about who should be leader, because of the division within the Labor Party itself. My first question is: how much money does the Department envisage will be available, on a year by year basis, over the next five years for capital grants to general practitioners?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Those figures are to be part of the negotiations that are being undertaken with the AMA and the Royal College of General Practitioners. It is not intended that they be disclosed prior to entering into the negotiations with those professional organisations.
—Do I understand, Minister, that you are not going to tell the Parliament what those figures are? You are not prepared to do so?

—The process set up is that the discussions will take place with the College and the AMA, and in order not to set those negotiations off on a wrong tangent or in a way that might prejudice the negotiations by publicly dealing with that matter, the figures are to be part of the discussions rather than part of the public debate at this time.

—I will come back to that matter later. Will general practices which accept capital grants be free to charge whatever fees they feel are reasonable? Will they be required to comply with the Government's medical benefits schedule, or will they be required to bulkbill universally?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is no commitment of that sort envisaged in the negotiations being undertaken.
—Is it not envisaged either way?

—I am told that in the negotiations it is not envisaged that there will be any requirement imposed in relation to, for example, the practice of having to bulkbill in providing services to its patients.
—So they may continue in the traditional way, setting their own fees regardless of what the Government's schedule fee might be?

—I understand that the Government has no intention of trying to impose on doctors the particular fee they will charge in relation to a particular service. I am not quite sure, but I think there would probably be a constitutional barrier to that anyway.

—There may not be in this particular case, if it is an agreement between the respective bodies. But I will pass on to the next question. I understand also that it is proposed that general practitioners will become budget holders on a trial basis. Will general practitioners be paid for managing a budget and, if so, what will be the level of remuneration?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Herron would expect me to say, that is precisely the type of matter that will properly be the subject of discussions.
—In determining which practices will attract capital grants, will priority be given to rural practices and practices in depressed areas?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the objectives of the overall policy is to try to remedy the maldistribution occurring at the moment in favour of rural and depressed areas. Whether the provision of capital amounts forms part of the mechanism to help achieve that objective has not been finally determined. I am not ruling it out as one of the ways in which that might be made a more attractive alternative.
—I refer the Minister back to the $3.50 reduction in the Medicare rebate to be followed by a $1.50 reduction next year. Is it intended that there will be further reductions beyond 1992?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can honestly say is that the Bill, which will be before this chamber on Friday in the committee stage, provides for this year and next year. As I understand it, no decisions have been taken in relation to following years. The Parliament is being presented with the proposal in so far as it relates to this financial year and the following financial year.
—I return to the issue of capital grants. How much does the Department envisage will be spent on administering capital grants this financial year and the following financial year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot break it down entirely, but some $350,000 is in the Budget for the overall administration of the whole bundle, if you like, relating to practice grants, some portion of which obviously could be attributed to dealing with the capital projects.

—I want to ask a question covered partly before in answer to a question by Senator Walters but put it a little differently. If a practice chooses to receive a capital grant, will that practice be able to use some of that grant simply to support the general practitioner's income?
—Just on general principles, I would imagine that if a grant is provided for a specific purpose it would be improperly used if it were not used for that purpose.
—Does the Department have plans for offering redundancy packages to general practitioners? If so, how much money has been set aside for this purpose this year and next financial year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Herron is really listing are all the items which are properly on the agenda for discussion. I understand that redundancy packages are part of the discussion being undertaken as a way in which we might deal with the oversupply problem. But the question of their being offered, the numbers, the way in which they might be funded or the extent to which they might be funded is not a matter known to me.
—If discussions break down and the royal colleges, the AMA and the other interested bodies refuse to pursue further discussion, is it the Government's intent to pursue its own agenda in this regard?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I know is that in mid-October Mr Howe, the Minister, apparently had a fruitful meeting with the leader of the Australian Medical Association and the Royal College of General Practitioners. It is on the basis of that worthwhile meeting that officials have already met twice to set down the agenda and the process for further negotiations, consultations and discussions. I do not envisage that there will be a breakdown. It seems to have a very good foundation at the moment. That is certainly the approach of the Government. It is not merely a hope; it is now based on the fact that the process has, as I say, got under way at the highest representative level and at the official working level.

—I revert now to a question that I have asked previously but have not received a satisfactory answer to. My question is simple: do doctors who bulkbill order more pathology tests than those who do not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can recall is that I provided Senator Herron with an answer of several paragraphs length on this issue. The difficulty was that most doctors do bulkbill at least their pensioner patients; therefore, it was difficult to come up with a division which provided a satisfactory answer to Senator Herron's question as to those who bulkbill and those who do not. It is not a simple division in the community of doctors. For that reason, the best I could do was to provide an answer the day after Senator Herron asked the question in this chamber.
—Has any work been done by the Minister's departmental officers in that regard to break that down to try to identify whether that occurs?

—I understand that some further work is being done to try to refine the data to allow those correlations to be made. If it can be achieved, I am sure that information will be very useful to the Government. I would not see why it cannot be supplied to the Senate. All that has been indicated to me is that an attempt is being made to try to correlate the material in a way which might be more helpful.
—I take it that the Minister will provide that to the Senate as soon as that information is available.

—I am saying that, if it is possible to achieve a greater refining of the material, it will obviously be of use in this debate and certainly of use to the Government. I undertake to seek the information, as I would after an ordinary question had been asked at Question Time.

—That last comment jogs my memory. When that is being done, would it be possible for the Minister to give an indication of the level of pathology services in those States which do not have entrepreneurial pathology bulkbilling practices as compared with those areas which do have them? I am particularly interested in Tasmania as compared with other places.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that Senator Harradine might be contrasting Tasmania with the mainland. If that material can be readily provided, I do not see why it should not be. The Senate has dealt with amendments to Bills and so on dealing with the problem of pathology services being over-ordered in certain practice situations, so it has already been the subject of discussion and action in this chamber. If we can find some more information we will provide it.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—We now move onto subprogram 6.1, entitled `Financial support to individuals'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. It would be useful for the information that was supplied to me from the Minister to be incorporated in Hansard. The Medicare abortion statistics indicate an horrific situation where funding of abortion is on the increase, with Medicare directly funding over 70,000 abortions a year in Australia at a cost of approximately $8m for the procedure itself. I ask the Minister for an indication of the extra amounts of money in associated costs. For example, is it a fact that when many abortions take place the aborted foetuses are subjected to pathology tests, and that that is an extra cost which is recouped by the abortion industry?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, as is Senator Harradine, faced with page after page of figures on this matter. I am told that if one looks at the material provided between pages 85 and 89 one will get an indication of the pathology tests that are provided in relation to abortion procedures. Is it right that Senator Harradine is after the overall cost?
—Apparently I don't have those pages. Presumably they have been provided to me, but I just don't have them here. If the figures are there I will not pursue the question at this stage.

—I note that five or six pages are provided. We will review the Hansard to see whether those pages answer the questions Senator Harradine has put this afternoon. If not, we will try to provide further material.
—Are there any questions on unanswered questions in the area of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a general question on the appropriation itself. The Minister will remember that on 15 October I asked Senator Button about the alteration in the appropriation in relation to the reduction from $3.50 to $2.50. The Minister may remember giving me an answer at the end of Question Time in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that there is no amount in the Appropriation Bills for Medicare rebates. There is a standing appropriation under section 125 of the Health Insurance Act for the Health Insurance Commission to spend what is needed for rebates.

The program performance statements for 1991-92 set out very clearly the reduction in the Medicare benefits at pages 196 and 197. Initially it was $3.50 and later $5. It sets out very clearly the changes to be made. Page 197 states:

Estimated outlays of $4,431.8m for 1991-92 represent an increase of $196.5m or 4.6% on outlays for 1990-91. An increased population base, a continuation of the historical increase in per capita utilisation and some fee drift (ie a shift towards more expensive services) offset by savings from benefit reductions, are estimated to account for $124m.
There is an estimate of the costs of Medicare benefits. Also, the Budget statement at page 3-63 states:

.The most important of the measures is a single package containing the following two major components relating to the introduction of further co-payments under Medicare and changes to general practitioner (GP) funding arrangements. Net savings are estimated at $163.9m in 1991-92 and $306.1m for 1992-93
Can the Minister tell me when this appropriation will be amended in the light of the new situation that has arisen and, indeed, the $12m that is now being appropriated a year early?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are two different things. One is the moneys that will be needed to fund the provision of Medicare funded services. That is done under a special Appropriation Act which is called the Health Insurance Act rather than under this set of Appropriation Bills. The point I am making is that the appropriation of moneys will be done under that Act, and I think that is the Act we will be looking at on Friday morning in the Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of bringing forward the funding for the practice grants which will require an extra $12m in expenditure, it is envisaged that that will be dealt with in the Supplementary Estimates. That will be an adequate procedure to deal with that expenditure.
The major matter, and the matter which I was addressing in my answer to Senator Hill in Question Time—to follow up Senator Walters's query—related to how Medicare funds are provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you inform me why it is in this particular document as to the estimated outlays?

—I think the document was trying to be as comprehensive as possible, and give a full picture of the health budget. The fact remains that the process of appropriations in the Medicare area is the same as in relation to social security benefits. These are done by separate Acts which, I suppose, take account of the fluctuating nature of the payments that might have to be made because of the different populations of those who might call on the services or the benefits they are entitled to.
—So you are saying that the estimated outlay of $4,431.8m for 1991-92 is not included in the appropriation under this Department?
—Yes, it is not in the annual appropriations; it is in the special appropriations which are dealt with in the Bill that we will be considering on Friday.
—That leaves us with the $12m which you say should be in this appropriation but is not.

—I did not exactly say that. I said it is envisaged by the Government that, given the timetable and so on, it can be adequately dealt with in the Additional Estimates which will be brought in by Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and which will be subject to proper debate by the Estimates committees in March or April next year.

—The news release put out by the Minister said that he was expecting that general practice reform should be undertaken as soon as possible. How come the $12m will not be needed prior to the special appropriations?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as some of these arrangements get under way— having given some answers this afternoon, one wonders how quickly they can be got under way—that can be covered by the Advance to the Minister for Finance, but the matter will come properly before the Estimates committee at the consideration of Supplementary Estimates.

—Minister, would it not be appropriate at least to amend the appropriations that are before us to the tune of that amount of money? Would that not be the correct way for the Government to go along the normal channels? It has now altered the Budget and has indicated that we are now to spend a considerable amount. If we leave out the additional cost of the change from $3.50 to $2.50, which the Minister says comes under a different Bill, that will have to be amended.
—No, it does not need to be amended, Senator.

—Well, I will leave that because I gather we will be dealing with that later. At least this appropriation should be amended because the Budget decision has been amended and we are now dealing with an additional $12m that was to be expended in 1992-93 but has now been brought forward to be expended in 1991-92.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand from the Department of Finance that it is normal practice that, where a proposal emerges after the presentation of Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) for additional funding, that is dealt with in the Additional Appropriation Bills submitted in the autumn session. That is the practice, and I have been given an example from a completely different field. That is the usual way in which these things are done. There is no departure from normal practice in this regard. Parliamentary scrutiny will remain. The obvious reason is to try to avoid changes over this long period which can be the case, depending on the way in which the Senate deals with the matters, between the second or third Tuesday in August through possibly to mid-November. Changes can occur and rather than amend those Bills, the practice is to deal with the matter in the supplementary estimates.
—Minister, I understand that, but you said that was after Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) are through. Well, they are not through.
—No; they are put before the Parliament.

—They have not been passed by the Parliament and therefore are able to be amended. I am asking whether the Minister will undertake to amend the Appropriation Bill in the way in which it should be done in the chamber because we will be voting on something that we know is inaccurate. To our knowledge, it is already inaccurate before the debate on the Appropriation Bills has taken place. We are only in the committee stages of that. Therefore, an amendment is able to be undertaken and I believe should be undertaken before this appropriation is voted upon.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Possibly Senator Walters has missed the point that I was making. The practice is that once the Appropriation Bills (No.1) and (No. 2) are put before the Parliament they remain intact. If something emerges that requires further expenditure, that can be dealt with in the ways I have indicated.

PARA.TAB: The example I intended to give from a completely different field is as follows. A need was identified late in 1990, but before the Appropriation Bills were passed, for an additional $25m to purchase Telecom's equity in Aussat. No attempt was made to amend the Appropriation Bills. Instead, the amount was provided for in the 1991 additional Appropriation Bills with interim funding provided from the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

I believe that is the way in which Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) are dealt with because the passage through the Parliament can take maybe one month, six weeks, eight weeks or three months. It is important that we not depart from a practice which has commended itself to the Parliament in the past. I see no reason to change that practice, particularly as all the processes will be available for proper consideration in the committees dealing with supplementary estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no other questions on the Department of Health, Housing and Community Affairs, we will move on.

—I am sorry, Mr Temporary Chairman, but the Minister will know that at the end of last night's proceedings I was asked whether I had finished. I indicated that I had not but had a couple more questions on HIV. I think that the Minister was to come back to me with a figure. The Department was informed by our Whip and we were asked whether we would mind leaving the matter until the end of consideration of Estimates Committee E, so that the officer concerned would not have to hang around.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the officer advising me spoke to the officer concerned this morning, who was busily trying to compile or to get the statistics or whatever it was Senator Walters required. That work is being undertaken. I can give an assurance that is being done in a way that is designed to provide Senator Walters with that information. It will be provided if it is humanly possible. That is what I understand the officer is working on at the moment. She is not here at present because she is engaged in that very process.

—I am sorry, but I think the Minister must have misunderstood me. I said that there were extra questions. The Minister will remember that I had not finished. I was in the middle of asking questions when Senator Harradine entered the questioning too. Last night's proceedings ended after 1 a.m. with Senator Harradine still asking questions.
—No, that is not right.
—I was then asked whether I had an additional question. I said yes, and the officer was to be back this evening. There is only the one question that I wish to put.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in this chamber at the time when Senator Hill and I asked around the chamber whether there were any more questions on the AIDS area. Because the answer to that was no, there was mutual agreement that we would close the debate. I am sorry, but I did not hear Senator Walters ask about a further question. However, if she has a question to put and we cannot answer it now, will she take it in good faith that we will take it on notice and provide her with the answer?

—This morning the Whip said to me that the officer said she knew that I had some more questions. As the Minister will know, there was great confusion because we had come to an agreement between our Whips that we adjourn. The fact that the Minister in the chamber chose to override that agreement was not my problem. I had left the chamber and therefore was not here. I was told by the Whips that we had come to an agreement to adjourn. I then responded to my Whip and said that I had another couple of questions.
—We did not know that. If I can, I will answer Senator Walters's question.

—The Whip did know and approached the Department to give me that information. The question is as follows. Could I have a copy of the certificate in prescribed form that is used by the Health Department for notifiable AIDS cases?
—That will be provided, Senator.
—I thank the Minister.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—That concludes our examination of that area. We will now move on to the estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by asking some questions based on answers given to Senator Alston in response to questions that were taken on notice. I refer to the computing service and the privatisation thereof. I would like some information on the progress of the industrial bans that have been in place now for a number of days and relate to the payment of allowances to veterans and the payment of accounts to service providers. What is the current situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that Senator Newman was given an answer to this question yesterday in response to a question she asked of Senator Cook during Question Time. The situation has not changed since then. The Department is still negotiating with the unions.
—Does that mean that no formal conciliation procedures have been introduced, that this is still at the departmental level?

—I am advised that there have been a number of appearances before the Commission; but, no, the matter has not moved to that formal stage and is still being handled by negotiations between the employers and the employees.

—I indicate to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, who has now returned to the chamber, that I am asking some further questions on the industrial bans, subsequent to the question I asked in Question Time yesterday. I understand that the conciliation process is still under way. How many officers are involved in this action?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are 34 in the core group at the computer site, and then there are ramifications throughout the Department.

—Is it true to say that at this stage no allowances are being paid at all and no accounts are being paid to service providers? If that is the true situation, can I have some quantification as to the number of people who have been affected and who should have been paid?
—Does the honourable senator mean by allowances the benefits that are payable to veterans?
—Allowances that are associated with pensioners.
—Such as?
—There is the travellers' allowance, the carers' allowance—a multitude of non-pension allowances.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, in relation to such things as carers' allowances, if a hardship case is presented it is dealt with manually. A real attempt is being made to ensure that no unnecessary hardship or distress is caused. As far as service providers are concerned—people such as domiciliary nurses and so on—once again I think the same principle is being implemented. Where it is possible to deal with a matter manually, that is being done, where clearly non-payment would result in hardship to the person concerned.
—A couple of questions arise from that answer. First, am I to take it that the Minister specifically referred only to carers' allowances? Is reimbursement of all those other allowances included?
—I was giving it as an example.

—That is fine. So anyone who is in difficulty as a result of not receiving the allowance that is due to him can make application for hardship reimbursement? I see from the officer's nod that that is so. My office has had a number of phone calls from domiciliary nurses in particular, and I am glad to know that at least there will be some way of giving them help. Is there any indication about how long this is going to be allowed to go on? At what stage do people get stood down in the Public Service for not doing the work for which they are paid?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not an expert in industrial relations but, as the honourable senator can imagine, the matter is receiving absolute priority as far as the Department is concerned and means are being attempted to resolve the dispute. However, given the decisions that have been announced by the Industrial Relations Commission and its supervision of the dispute and its resolution, I would imagine that the process would be very much under its aegis. I point out that there is obviously no desire on the part of the Department that this matter should go on for any longer.

—The Minister will recall that Senator Cook said yesterday that he believed that it was deplorable. I understand that it has been at least a fortnight, and I wonder how long the Minister can stand by. The Minister referred to the fact that the Industrial Relations Commission has had some involvement. Precisely what is that involvement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: - Simply that the matter has been subject to hearings in the Industrial Relations Commission. That is what I was referring to.
—A decision has been handed down?
—An order was handed down, yes.
—When was that and what was the order?
—The order was made on 31 October. I think the Commission ordered bans to be lifted. That was the core of it, and that is the situation at the moment.

—So that means we are talking about illegal bans once the Commission has made such an order. There must be a normal procedure in the Public Service when there is such an order from the Industrial Relations Commission. What is the next step and why has it not been taken? Six to seven days have passed since that order was made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot recall Senator Cook's answer to the honourable senator but I think it was to the extent that, rather than a strong confrontation at this point, agencies like the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Industrial Relations were seeking to find a way to help achieve a resolution of this matter. The matter is being pursued in the way which we believe will in the end provide for what we want; that is, services to veterans being provided in a fully available way instead of the fragmented way which is the case at the moment.

—I thank the Minister, but of course he could not expect that I would find it satisfactory. Firstly, for the Department itself and for all those officers who have served the cause of veterans for so long and so well, it is reflecting extremely badly on that Department and the tradition of those officers. For that I am extremely sad. A few people are tearing down the good relationship that has existed for many years between veterans and that Department; that is the first thing. Secondly, these employees of the Commonwealth who are in a very privileged position right now, with security of employment and security of tenure, when their countrymen are out of work, walking the streets looking for jobs, are being allowed to get away with not doing the job for which they are being fully paid. I do not accept that the Government is treating this matter with the urgency it deserves.

PARA.TAB: My final point is that these officers in their dispute with the Government are taking it out on the people who have fought for this country and the people who provide those veterans with the services to which they are entitled by way of compensation. How long can some of these domiciliary nurses and other health providers continue to provide a service for which they are not paid? Some of those domiciliary nurses are providing the only income to their households, are the sole parents or sole breadwinners in a family where the other spouse is out of work. Now, it seems to be that in Canberra, in protected Canberra, we can have this matter wander along in a very gentle way. I do not regard it as a gentle matter. For those reasons I regard it as extremely serious. I do not see the sense of urgency that I would have thought the Department and the Repatriation Commission would have felt on such an important matter. I am very disgusted.

Having said that, I would like to turn to some other matters. Referring to program 1, I would like to raise some questions about the defence service home loans. In response to questions which were taken on notice by the Department, it was explicitly stated that the 8 January amendment to subsection 4(1) of the Defence Service Homes Act was intended only to preserve the entitlement of one partner for later use. Given that the 8 January amendment has not had the effect intended, will the Department be seeking to further amend the legislation, and what section should have been amended to achieve the desired result?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will take me a minute to get some information. All I can say at the moment is that the issues are complex. Legal consideration is not yet completed, for example, as to whether the current legislation allows the second party's entitlement to be used to discharge any secondary borrowings related to the DSH loan granted on the eligibility of the first party. As far as I am aware, that is the situation at the moment.

—I thank the Minister. I found that a little hard to follow but I have a number of questions on this matter. I hope we will be able to get through them and see whether we can do any better with the rest. Is it true that at the AAT hearing considering the Moir case jointly with the Kinsman case, counsel representing the Department, in an opening submission to the AAT hearing, offered to concede on the matters before the tribunal, thereby acknowledging the correctness of the Moir appeal?
—I am advised that is not the case.
—My advice is that it is the case. Was the Moir case the first of its type to be appealed to the AAT?
—Yes. The Kinsman and Moir cases apparently were joint cases or at least were taken on at the same time. They were the first of their kind.

—Does the Department accept that in paragraph 24 of the AAT ruling on the Kinsman case Justice O'Connor said, `The overall scheme of the Act and the various provisions were supportive of the applicant's case' and that it was a technicality rather than an intended provision that led to an affirmation of the Department's decision?
—I do not know whether he said that. I presume—
—She.
—She, Senator.
—Judges are women also.
—Yes, and they wear wigs more naturally.
—Justice is usually portrayed as a woman.
—Is that the case heard by Justice O'Connor on 14 February 1991?
—Yes.
—Also, at the Department's request Justice O'Connor considered the effects of the amendments to the Act that came into force on 8 January.
—Yes.

—I am advised that Justice O'Connor upheld the decision taken under the legislation as it stood prior to the 8 January 1991 amendments but went on to observe that as a result of the amendments this position could no longer be sustained. Following the decision, DSH officers were advised to inform clients that the matter of concurrent entitlements was under review. On 22 August the Minister announced concurrent use of entitlements would be allowed.

—I thank the Minister. I think we are on the same wavelength. Is it the case that Justice O'Connor has reserved her decision on the Moir v. the Secretary to Department of Veterans' Affairs case pending further submissions from both parties? Also, in the opinion of the Department, why was this action taken?

—As I understand it, Moir has decided not to proceed and is pursuing a compensation claim, presumably disagreeing with the AAT decision, asserting there is an entitlement under the previous legislation.

—I suppose this then becomes a hypothetical question but I would like to ask it. Given that the Moir v. the Secretary case is being conducted according to the legislation as it stood before 8 January, does the Minister accept that, if the case was resumed and a definitive judgment was made in favour of the applicants, the actions of the Department in respect of denying concurrent defence service home loans could be deemed illegal?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General's Department has advised the Department of Veterans' Affairs that there is strong authority for the view that, where properly considered advice is given in respect of complex questions of statutory construction, even if the advice is subsequently found to be incorrect, this does not lead automatically to the conclusion that there has been any negligence—that is, breach of duty of care on the part of the persons giving that particular advice. Notwithstanding the legal situation as explained, should any people claim that they have suffered a loss as a result of any advice which may have been received from DSH, each such claim will be considered on its merits.

PARA.TAB: I might just mention one other interesting point. A search of DSH records reveals that no applications for concurrent assistance were rejected in the period from 8 January, the date of the effect of the legislative change, and the handing down of the Kinsman decision on 26 April. Any persons applying after the date of the Kinsman decision but before the Minister's announcement of 22 August were advised that it was under review and applications were held pending the outcome of that review.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disregarding the 8 January amendment, what specific section of the legislation was deemed to have prevented the granting of the concurrent loans?
—The officer cannot give me an answer as to the precise section involved.

—I presume that the action that was taken prior to the Kinsman case was based on something; it was just not based on a hunch but was an interpretation of the Act. I would like to have the information, even if this question has to be taken on notice. Was there a set of guidelines or a policy document that said that concurrent eligibility was not possible prior to 8 January? How is such a matter decided within the Department?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there was a longstanding interpretation of the legislation to that effect. Whether it was recorded in some sort of document that accompanied the legislation, some sort of manual of interpretation, can be found out. If so, that information can be provided.

—I would just like to make sure that it is not folklore. Has the Department or the Minister received any advice from any other agency suggesting action which might be taken to address the concerns of those who may have revoked their defence service homes entitlement in the absence of the knowledge of the ruling on concurrent eligibility?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Department does accept that some may feel themselves to be disadvantaged. It is expected that the Government will bring forward legislation in the autumn sittings to address that matter.
—That is very good; I am very pleased.
—Would Senator Newman put out a press statement saying that?

—The Minister does something right sometimes, even if he has to be prodded. I was also going to be a bit rude about the Minister because he took from 15 August, when I wrote to him about the concurrent loan issue, to 28 October to reply to the letter—2 1/2 months later—on a matter which was of some urgency to the people involved. It struck me that there did not seem to be a very great sense of urgency or concern about it. However, when I did get the letter from the Minister dated 28 October, the Minister told me that he was concerned about the situation of people who might have been disadvantaged and, with the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), he was reviewing the options with a view to reaching a satisfactory solution. I am just wondering whether the Senator Tate has some information available as to a satisfactory solution.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The details are to be worked out but, in principle, there is an acknowledgment of the situation and a remedy will be provided, as I understand it, in legislation to be brought in during the autumn session. I do not know the exact nature of it.

—I think the Minister missed the point, or perhaps I did not make it clear enough. Some people will now be able to put themselves back into a position where they could have concurrent eligibility. What about the people who took action based on what they were told was the situation and were financially disadvantaged as a result? Is there some solution for those people?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are taking further advice on the sort of problem that Senator Newman is again bringing to our attention. Advice is being sought and it could be available to the Department within a matter of days or next week. The matter is being looked at, and it is being looked at in order to try to deal with the situation in a fair way.
—I presume that I will be told of the solution as soon as the Minister knows it.
—Yes.
—Has the Government had any input from Westpac and the National Australia Bank in the resolution of this problem?
—I understand that discussions have taken place with Westpac and responses in relation to these matters are expected quite soon.
—In other words, the previous answer also related to the consultation with the banks.
—Is Senator Newman asking whether I will make available to her the result of the discussions with the banks?

—No, not particularly. I was wanting to know the end result as to what the Government will do for these people. I presume that the Minister will do something partly as a result, with consultations with the two banks because they were involved in the issue.
—Yes.

—To conclude that section, I feel it is only fair to give the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) a big tick. In the correspondence between the Departments of Veterans' Affairs and Defence Science and Personnel that has been given to me by the Department, Mr Humphreys and his Department come out of this as being pretty caring of people caught up in this situation. I cannot say the same for Mr Bilney, whose correspondence is clearly much more concerned about the National Australia Bank's or Westpac's interests than about compensating or putting right people who have been caught up through no fault of their own by an incorrect interpretation of the law. I was extremely disappointed in the letter that Mr Bilney sent to Mr Humphreys which was signed on 9 August. It was extremely disappointing from a man whose job it is to look after the defence personnel. Clearly, their interests were very low down the totem pole.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the question of war widows. At the Additional Estimates hearings last April, Mr Volker, the Secretary of the Department of Social Security, said that a review of the anomalies affecting war widows was being conducted by his Department together with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It was suggested that the review would be concluded in time for the Budget. Does the Department of Veterans' Affairs acknowledge anomalies which are faced by war widows, and is this view shared by the Department of Social Security?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that discussions are still taking place between the Ministers concerned as to a view which could be taken of this situation and that negotiations between the Ministers have not yet been concluded. Therefore, I cannot give a definitive answer.

—I am disappointed. I did rather expect that we would see action in the Budget and I was going to ask the Minister why none was taken. I presume it has just stalled, has it? Is the Minister in any position to give me any information on the options which were canvassed for addressing the anomalies and the projected costs of these options?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think not; those matters are still being discussed at ministerial level and are subject to that highest level consideration. So all the options that might be considered by the Ministers are matters for them: they can either adopt one or none or a combination of some.

—Am I correct in understanding that they have not yet gone to Cabinet, that they are not yet Cabinet documents, that they are still subject to negotiations and discussions between the departments at officer level? Why is it that the Committee is not able to ask questions about it and get a copy of the reports that have been prepared by the departments on this issue?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had indicated that the discussions were at the ministerial level and still awaiting responses at that level. It is because of that level of discussion that I believe that the various options ought to be regarded as being of a status which means that, for good decision making in the preparation of ministerial advice to the Cabinet, the various options at this time ought to be kept to the Ministers concerned.
—Can the Minister tell me how many war widows the Department has identified who are subject to discrimination?
—I understand that there are some 50,000 who could be described in that way.

—Is there any way the Minister can give me a ballpark indication of when these decisions will be made or how far down the track we will wait? It was suggested to us that the review would be concluded in time for the Budget. It has now dragged on a great deal longer than that. When shall we expect it?

—The final resolution of this matter, if it involves considerable expenditure, is obviously a matter which is properly dealt with in the Budget context, given the levels of expenditure. That would be the time at which the final resolution of the matter would become apparent.

—Does the Minister think it will be in an election Budget instead? For the benefit of Hansard, I take it that the Minister's smile means that I could be right but he is not going to confirm it. I turn now to the question of the integration of the repatriation hospitals.

PARA.TAB: Given that the Tasmanian and the Federal governments have reached agreement on the transfer of the Hobart Repatriation General Hospital to the State, can details on the financial and any special access arrangements now be made available?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that whilst agreement in principle has been reached there is still some finetuning of the aspects to be undertaken and that neither government is at the stage where it is willing to put this set of arrangements on the public record. As Senator Newman quite rightly says, the agreement has been reached but it is a question of further discussions taking place.
—Can the Minister please tell me which aspects have not been finalised?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are quite basic matters on finalising the exact running costs of the RGH and other matters that are still at the stage of requiring further deliberation and clear conclusions. I can give Senator Newman some broad aspects.

PARA.TAB: In brief, the Commonwealth will pay a bed day rate for acute care patients which reflects the agreed costs of providing treatment. It will also provide some additional assistance to enable the State to rationalise its services as well as some funding for capital works at the RGH. If a suitable location is found for relocation of the palliative care unit, subject to undertakings in relation to quality of care, the Commonwealth will guarantee that the State will not be financially disadvantaged in the first three years after integration.

The agreement also provides an appropriate review mechanism, together with monitoring arrangements involving Tasmanian ex-service organisations. However, the precise details of the proposed financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and Tasmania for the treatment of veterans and their eligible dependants are a matter of confidence at this stage and are still being refined in some areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit rum when today we have the legislation introduced into the House of Representatives, which will make this whole dirty deal legal, yet the taxpayers who may have an extra bill or may have a saving do not know a single bit of hard information about the costs. Not only that but they are also being asked to support legislation really on a `trust me' basis.

PARA.TAB: This Government's reputation with the veterans' community is such that I do not think there are too many veterans who would take it on trust any more. So to be introducing legislation that has to be decided upon in the dark is rather a foolhardy exercise on the part of the Government. Why would the Government get so far down the track and not be prepared to tell the Parliament the financial details? Why should anybody be asked to decide upon legislation which is to underwrite this whole exercise?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We ought to wait until we have the legislation available for consideration in the chamber. As I understand it, it is directed to giving guarantees and assurances to veterans on services available to them. That is the purpose of the legislation. That is rather independent of the sorts of questions that Senator Newman is asking, which are legitimate questions. But, given the stage of the negotiations in support of the in-principle agreement, for example, in Tasmania, I am unable at the moment to provide Senator Newman with those figures that she seeks.

—The taxpayer, of course, would consider them to be very legitimate questions. I find it strange that the Government should be rushing headlong into introducing legislation into the Parliament until such time as these details are finalised. What is the urgency? Why should the Government wish to proceed before it is able to tell us these things, before they are even agreed between the parties?

PARA.TAB: Not only are they of concern to the taxpayers but they are also of vital concern to the veterans. If there are substantial savings to be made under these agreements to the revenue, the taxpayer may be very pleased but the veterans will be very suspicious. I should have thought it was a pretty crucial matter for everybody to know before this Parliament was asked to vote.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only reiterate that the legislation is being sought by the veterans in order that these guarantees might be legislatively expressed and given a statutory imprimatur of this Parliament. That is what will be sought to be done by way of that legislation. I have not said that Senator Newman's questions are not legitimate or fair ones in relation to the question of the effects on taxpayers of these arrangements. But at this moment, given the state of negotiations, the information that Senator Newman requires on the precise financial arrangements cannot be provided to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just happen to have a press release that was put out by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs today entitled `Legislation guarantees new health deal for veterans', which does not guarantee all that much at all. As I have said already, I find it very hard to support any legislation when the details are not signed and sealed. Clearly, that is the case with the Tasmanian agreement. That is the only agreement at this stage which is in the offing. I was interested that the Minister, in a three-page press release, found it difficult, well nigh impossible, to say that this legislation was being introduced at the wish of the veterans. The Minister draws a bit of a long bow in the second last paragraph on the third page of the press release. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr. Humphreys also acknowledged the legislation could not have been developed without the co-operation and support of representatives of the RSL, the T & PIs, the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, the Repatriation Defence Forces Welfare Association, Legacy and the War Widows' Guild.

There is no enthusiasm, there is no support, and the Minister knows it. He cannot say that this legislation is being introduced with the support of the veterans. If Senator Tate has been told that, he has been misinformed. I would expect that Senator Tate would know his own constituents better than that. It was indicated at the Committee hearing that the Department has had broad estimates prepared on the cost of implementation of the so-called private patients scheme. Can I have these estimates?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have anything to provide to Senator Newman at the moment. Some of these matters still have Cabinet-in-confidence status and are still being negotiated with the States, but I am advised that in so far as that material can be made available at a future date it will be.
—That will be after we have had an opportunity to decide whether we will pass the legislation.
—I do not know what the timing will be.

—I found it quite interesting that the legislation does not make any claims about financial impact. Clearly, whether it is in negotiations with the States or the actual cost of the so-called private patients scheme, if all of those things are still up in the air, the Government is very premature in trying to bring this legislation in at all, as I have said already. Can I please have details of the proposed monitoring committees that are to be established for the monitoring of the veterans hospital care post integration? Who will the committees report to? What input will they have in Government decision-making?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

PARA.TAB: To anticipate Senator Newman's next question, when I said `a representative of the national executive', I understand those bodies will nominate the person. The same applies at the State level.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wanted to know what input they will have in Government decision-making and how effective they can be. What will be the status of their recommendations?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have indicated that, certainly at the national level and no doubt mirrored at the State level, the status of the committee is very high, given the representation on it. —I would not be all that confident. I thank the Minister for his opinion. Has the PSU accepted the DVA-ACTU agreement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that all unions have agreed, except for the PSU. There has been agreement reached with officials of the PSU. I understand there must be a mechanism for it to put the matter to its members. We do not know the response on that.

—How many other hospitals are there in each State that DVA is currently negotiating with? I would also like to know the bed capacity of those hospitals.

—What are the latest figures available to the Department on percentage of treatment population in relation to distance from an RGH for each State?
—We will provide that information.

—Last week there was a report in the Hobart Mercury concerning a ward at the repatriation hospital in Hobart which was closed following the discovery of an organism. The organism was wrongly described in the report as a viral organism; I believe it is a bacterium. The article said that the staphylococcus aureus was resistant to methicillin, I think, and it was found in a patient who was transferred from another hospital. Could the Minister tell me which hospital that patient was transferred from?
—Officers do not have with them information as to the originating hospital.
—It is pretty important.
—I am sure it will be going to the health authorities.

—I would hope so. I would like to draw the Minister's attention to a number of things that are contained in that article. I understand that it is good and firm medical practice that a patient is not transferred from another hospital until a nasal swab is done. Why was that not done in this case?
—Are you inferring that from the article or do you say that is in the article?

—When a patient is being transferred from one hospital to another, the proper medical practice is to do a nasal swab before that transfer is implemented. Clearly, that cannot have been done in this case.

—I am told that it is a common practice. Whether it is obligatory or mandatory or a procedure that is assumed to have been done without any particular checking by the receiving hospital is something I do not know. We will find out what the situation is.

—The article in the Mercury states that 10 patients were removed from the ward after the organism was found. Also, the acting chief executive for the hospital, Mr Norm Davie, was reported as saying that MRSA was not considered dangerous and should not be confused with the more commonly known golden staph. The medical advice I have had, which was firstly about the nasal swab, is that this can kill, which is fairly dangerous to anybody, I would have thought, and particularly to elderly people such as we have in the repatriation hospital. That is why I am particularly concerned that proper procedures were not followed. I am not suggesting that the repatriation hospital was responsible for the nasal swab, but I want to know which hospital transferred a patient into a repatriation hospital without following the proper procedures in a situation which is a matter of life and death.

—I think Senator Newman is making valid points about proper medical practice. I believe that it is a matter about which we need to get some more information. Certainly, if that advice which appears in the press from the acting chief executive of the hospital is bad medical advice, then it ought to be checked.

—We all know we can be misreported by the newspapers, so I give the acting chief executive the benefit of the doubt. But some things in this article are in quotes. The ward was closed and isolated to ensure the health and safety of patients, which obviously meant that this matter was being taken pretty seriously. The executive said that the ward would reopen in about 10 days. I am also told that, once that particular bacterium is found in a hospital, it is extremely difficult to eradicate. It can be present in a hospital for years. So we are not just playing around. I am concerned to think that the repatriation hospital is being used as an overflow hospital. Are we already seeing the first stage of what integration into the State hospital system will mean for veteran health care in Hobart? I am sure the Minister can understand why I am so concerned. I hope he shares my concern. We need to get this information and we need it urgently. When does the Minister think he will be able to get it to me?
—I have asked officials to attempt to get information as to the proper medical procedures and status of the presence of this bacterium by Question Time tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane's question concerns the National Health and Occupational Safety Commission, officially known as Worksafe Australia. It is a body chaired by Mr Lou Marks, a distinguished commercial figure with a commercial background in transport.

The Committee of Worksafe Australia has set down a series of priority areas in which one can rationally direct attention to achieve the most valuable impact for money spent on research. I do not have the list in front of me, but I do know that it concerns investigation into back pain, the use of certain chemical materials and so on. There are a number of priority areas.

My understanding of how funds are allocated is that Worksafe has a budget for allocation. Those priority areas are indicated to the world at large and groups interested in doing research or undertaking projects which assist in furthering knowledge about occupational health and safety then apply. They are assessed by this representative body and grants are given according to the type of project, the priority Worksafe has for it and the capacity of the organisation to deliver a result that is useful and meaningful. Senator Crane asked what happens in the case of an organisation with funds for a project or some research not expending the full value of the money that has been allocated.
