TALK.START.PARA: —Every so often the misallocation of public resources becomes so glaring and unjust that it is necessary to raise the issue in this chamber. Tonight I wish to draw the attention of the Senate, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) to a very real problem that exists in the far north of Western Australia. Broome may have developed a growing national reputation as a tourist destination but the Kimberley region has more than its share of social dislocation.

PARA.TAB: One agency that is fighting valiantly to provide crisis accommodation and family support is Catherine House. Anyone who visits there, as I did not so many months ago, cannot fail to be impressed with the dedication of its staff and with the enormity of the problems that they face. For 16 years Catherine House has been providing crisis accommodation to children whose families have broken down. While it does not cater exclusively for Aboriginal families, it is true to say that more than 90 per cent of its clients are Aboriginal, as are half of its board members.

What I am talking about may not be an Aboriginal program per se. However, it is a clear commonsense issue involving Aboriginal welfare. This is not only a matter of accommodating children until their family situation has stabilised. Over the past year parents have been referred to alcohol rehabilitation and other specialised services, or have benefited from individual programs of the family support service. I should mention here the work that has been done by Christina Seenikatty, the coordinator at Catherine House, in the fight against the causes of family breakdown among Aboriginal people.

It must be stressed that in the entire Kimberley region there is no other such support service, and Catherine House must also cater for Derby and Fitzroy Crossing. In the first six months of this year 70 children who were the victims of neglect, abuse and domestic violence were accommodated in Catherine House. Some of the children placed in Catherine House are seriously disturbed and violent, which increases pressure on the staff. Turnover of cottage parents is very high, not because of any lack of dedication—far from it—but purely and simply because of burn-out.

I would like to pay a special tribute to the work of Christina Seenikatty, who has kept the refuge operating while having to devote more and more of her time to the writing of submissions for funding. I was sad to hear today that Christina has now had to leave because of a lack of funding. She has done a wonderful job, as have so many of the house parents and cottage parents. Their work has been very much an integral part of what has been going on at Catherine House.

This essential service is threatened by lack of funds. To provide an acceptable minimum service Catherine House needs $171,000 annually, only part of which is met by the Western Australia Department of Community Services. With the burden of WA Inc., there is not much chance of increased support by the State Government. I hope that the Federal Government will see reason on this particular issue.

What is needed is a further $91,000 annually to enable Catherine House to survive and continue its essential community work, with some respite for a staff that presently functions at 2.3 full time units. Only this week the axe has fallen, with the coordinator's position and the family support services being discontinued. Catherine House will remain open for crisis accommodation but nothing can now be done to tackle the problems that make its continued operation necessary. Aboriginal families are the very big losers.

I am well aware, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has explained, that child welfare services are primarily a State responsibility and that the ATSIC budget for the Broome region for 1991-92 has been exhausted. I understand that the possible funding avenues through the Federal Department of Health, Housing and Community Services have also been exhausted.

There comes a time, however, when all these reasoned excuses have to take second place to meeting the most urgent needs of Aboriginal Australians. We have to remember that Commonwealth spending on Aboriginals exceeds $1 billion, with $640m allocated to ATSIC for 1991-92. When Catherine House cannot afford even to replace a vacuum cleaner or repair a television set, as I learned this week, I just wonder where some of these funds have gone.

It is particularly ironic that on 25 October Australia Council Aboriginal arts grants totalling $2.2m were released. Of these, 28 grants totalling $524,000 were provided in Western Australia, and those awarded in Broome itself for writers, arts administration, music and oral history total just under $180,000. The grants in Broome alone are double the amount that Catherine House is asking, remembering that it needs only a further $91,000 annually to enable it to survive. But here we are talking about a sum of $180,000 in the Broome area alone in respect of arts. When other grants in the Kimberley are included, we are looking at close to $290,000 in Australia Council largess. As I have said, Catherine House services the whole of the Kimberley. When one pits $91,000 that is required for this essential service against $290,000 given out in arts grants it is all a little strange.

We do not need to be told that this money comes out of a separate department altogether but we have to remember that it all comes from the same source, namely from Australian taxpayers. The taxpayers of Western Australia whom I represent do not necessarily criticise arts grants to Aboriginal Australians or anyone else. Indeed, there are Aboriginal people with real and magnificent artistic talent in Broome, and I am not suggesting that the recipients of the $180,000 were undeserving in any way. I know that they are deserving, but I think the Aboriginal communities must also decide among themselves what is more deserving. Is it a question of trying to keep Catherine House going, or is it more important to promote their arts and culture?

Nonetheless, people have the right to ask why this Government, why our society, finds money for writers' grants when the most essential of services for the most disadvantaged members of the Kimberley community have to be so tragically curtailed. I really wonder why a society that gives Mr Michael Mansell $15,000 to write a book on social and political relationships plays pass the parcel on the matter of funding a refuge for Aboriginal children and providing support for their families. It is very illogical. It is only fair to note that the Australia Council has also announced 29 grants, totalling $1.2 million, for the performing arts in Western Australia. Again, I do not dispute the worthiness of many of the recipients, but I must ask once more: where are our national priorities? These grants include $8,000 for the Public Sector Union, a mere drop in the ocean when added to the $30 million—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like banning veterans payments.

—That is exactly right. It is a bit like banning the veterans' payments, as Senator Newman says. That is a very important comparison, because we have these two areas of the community that are fighting for survival, that are fighting for money, yet we seem to have money allocated everywhere else. As I say, the grants include $8,000 for the Public Sector Union. Considering the $30m granted under various headings to unions by this Labor Government up to June last year, where is the justice? In public life we all hear complaints that we live in an imperfect world with demands that we should solve problems overnight through `Where there's a will there's a way', as the old saying goes. Very often, as we all know, that is too simplistic. But is it simplistic and unreasonable for us to ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to start pulling levers, to start looking into hollow logs, to defer non-essential spending, and to talk to the Western Australian Government just to make sure that Aboriginal children and families in the Kimberley community do not lose this essential support?

PARA.TAB: Until we can get our priorities right and fund those dedicated institutions and their staff—which must cope with the consequences of family breakdown, alcoholism and a whole range of other problems—we have no right to call ourselves a compassionate society; we would have to say that we are a very wasteful and stupid one. I hope that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, as a Western Australian, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table at the moment and who is a Western Australian but now not living in Western Australia, will take some interest in Catherine House and make sure that it does continue and that these Aboriginal children and their families are not just dumped in a ditch and left to die. Very many good people have put in an enormous amount of time to provide an excellent facility in a very remote region of Australia. I certainly hope that the money can be found—a mere $91,000—to keep Catherine House going.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United States Joint Facilities in Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what my fellow Western Australian senator has said about the funding for Catherine House. I think it is important that it does get the support that it needs to continue operating. The subject that I want to address tonight concerns something that has been bothering me over the past few days, and that is the question of the role of the so-called joint US-Australian facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. There has been a lot of confusion over the role of these bases in the past few days following the publication of Professor Des Ball's article in the Asia-Pacific Defence Reporter. I think it is important to put on record some of the contradictory and probably deliberately confusing information concerning these facilities, particularly that emanating from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and from the Department of Defence—or is it a case of the relevant Ministers not knowing what is going on? In either case, it is pretty appalling.

PARA.TAB: When I asked the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) about the role of the facilities following the recent changes announced by the United States and the Soviet Union with regard to the deployment of nuclear forces, I was told once again that it is not the Government's policy to comment on the role of the joint facilities or to speculate publicly about their future roles. We now learn from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, through his speech to the National Press Club on 4 November, that the United States had informed Australia that sharing early warning data with the Soviets was under consideration when the US President, Mr Bush, announced his nuclear arms cuts at the end of September. He quite clearly said that on 4 November.

In other words, the Government knew perfectly well that changes were under way, yet all Senator Ray could say to me on 8 October was that I should refer to the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives in 1988, a statement which is totally irrelevant in the enormously rapidly changing international climate. It is tragic that, even though the Cold War and the era of East-West confrontation is over, the Australian Government chooses to perpetuate the obsessive secrecy characteristic of the past era and refuses to allow any community discussion about the future of these bases.

Yesterday, we learned what the peace movement had alleged all along was the role of Nurrungar during the Gulf war, although at the time the Government again refused to confirm or deny the allegations. We have been saying for years and years that Nurrungar has a war fighting role as well as a verification and arms monitoring role. In fact, the arms control agreements that Pine Gap and Nurrungar are meant to monitor were not even in place when the bases were established. This has been our claim over many years and we have now been proved to be absolutely right.

For 20 years, both coalition and Labor governments have refused to acknowledge the roles of the bases. But, finally, it was spelt out yesterday in the Senate by the Minister for Defence. That was highly overdue. Of course, it was still a denial not only that the role of the bases was important in the early warning of Scud missiles emanating from Iraq during the Gulf war but also that all the information was important for the so-called strategic bombing by the coalition forces of the Iraqis. It was very clearly a war fighting role. Anyone familiar with the strategic role of such facilities knows perfectly well what they are about. Many books and articles have referred to these roles, but the Australian Government has continued its pattern of obsessive secrecy by refusing to comment on the role of what are in effect US bases on Australian soil.

We had hopes that, with the changing global situation, this Government would take up the opportunities presented by re-examining Australia's commitment to a military alliance drawn up and signed at the height of the Cold War and to the role of these bases that were set up just over 20 years ago to serve US global strategic requirements. But, no, all we get from Senator Ray is a comment that ANZUS had proved its durability and relevance over a period of 40 years and that he was confident that it would prove to be just as durable into the foreseeable future. Alliances come and go, and when they are no longer relevant they sink into the dustbin of history, like the South East Asia Treaty Organisation and the Baghdad Pact, and it is about time that the ANZUS alliance sank into that dustbin of history as well.

The obfuscation continues with the role of Nurrungar since the changes announced by the United States and the Soviet Union. According to an ALP report on 4 November, a senior Australian defence official had said on the previous night that the Australian Government was well aware that Soviet military personnel `might' inspect the Nurrungar facility, and the Sun-Herald of the same day quotes the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) as saying that the Australian Government was unaware of a US invitation to the Soviet Union to inspect a secret missile tracking base in South Australia, adding that he expected that the process of `demystifying' Nurrungar would continue soon. It can hardly be a continuation when the previous pattern has been obsessive secrecy. But, of course, Mr Bilney knew something then, which of course Senator Ray did reveal to the Senate yesterday.

The Australian Financial Review of 4 November quoted Senator Evans as saying that he was unaware of any US proposals to allow the Soviet Union to share nuclear early warning data from joint US-Australian bases. It reported:
`I am not being evasive,' he said. `I just have not read or heard anything which is sharply focused on any implications for the operations of the facilities.'

SPEECH.PARA: Next day, the same paper quoted Senator Evans as confirming that the US was considering sharing nuclear early warning information from the joint bases. He told the Press Club:

PARA.TAB: In that particular context at that time there was a communication from the US Government to our Government saying that the US was thinking about discussing sharing that warning information with the Soviet Union, but that the US would, of course, consult with Australia before pursuing that further.
It was something that flowed from the Bush statement and at the very time of that statement we were told about it—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the statement about the cuts in nuclear weapons—
and told of the possibility of information flowing from the joint facilities and promised, of course, consultations before that was pursued further.

The report later says that a spokesman for Senator Evans had said that he had not known of these proposals because they were at a preliminary stage, and to quote the official in Senator Evans's office:

PARA.TAB: I just don't think the pieces of paper were put up to him.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an appalling situation for the Foreign Affairs Minister not to be told about what was under discussion: this very significant information. This was also the line taken by Senator Evans in Question Time today when he referred to the vast amount of paper on his desk and the fact that he could not deal with it all at once.

PARA.TAB: However, on 5 November Senator Ray told Senator Spindler that there had been no approach from the United States to explore the possibility of expanding the current so-called joint facilities, or expanding new ones. The Minister then told Senator Faulkner that Professor Des Ball was jumping to conclusions in suggesting Soviet access to Nurrungar data and especially in relation to Soviet visits to Nurrungar. He went on to say that US officials have assured us that no discussions have been held with the USSR about sharing data from Nurrungar or about Soviet visits to Nurrungar, adding that none are currently contemplated. Now, when I attempted to ask more about what was going on in Question Time today, in light of these conflicting reports, I was once again fobbed off with a non-answer. The Minister confused is not a pretty sight. The Minister waffling is bad enough. The Minister not knowing what is going on is a disgrace. Two Ministers not knowing what is going on or deliberately misleading the Parliament is appalling.

What sort of government to government communication did Senator Evans allude to, both at the Press Club the other day and here in the Parliament today? It is very clear, he says, that there was a government to government communication. Was it a cable, a telex, a phone call, a letter or some other form that we know not of? Was it another Bush-Hawke phone call towards the end of September? President Bush is renowned for getting on the telephone and buzzing international leaders to inform them of his latest international strategic plans. Did he buzz Bob Hawke towards the end of September and say `Well, Bob, I am about to announce significant cuts in nuclear tactical weapons and this is going to have an effect on New Zealand, of course, and I neither confirm nor deny that a treaty is up for deliberation. It is going to embarrass the New Zealand Government into trying to change its policy on denying nuclear ships visits. It might have an effect on Australia also regarding the bases.'? Was there some phone call like that that we had not yet heard about? We just do not know what sort of government to government communication there was. However, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade says there was one: the Minister for Defence says there has been no approach and it is not likely in the future.

The Minister for Defence is totally unaware, if we are to believe his statements to Senator Spindler and Senator Faulkner yesterday, of these developments. It is interesting too that he was so dismissive of Professor Des Ball's claims, a tactic the previous Minister for Defence also used against Professor Ball's findings about Nurrungar's SDI links, which of course they have not bothered to refute in detail or in substance. That would give too much away. But Professor Ball is generally recognised as the expert in Australia on the operation of the US bases in this country. His research is painstaking and he is not likely to make empty or extravagant claims. As I said, the Government has never before proved him wrong. Whether there are Soviet personnel due to visit Nurrungar or not is beside the point. What is very significant is the proposal to share information gleaned through Pine Gap and Nurrungar with the Soviets or anyone else.

As a supporter of Glasnost and having consistently called for transparency in arms transfers, I support the sharing of information for peaceful purposes, but of course not for war-fighting roles, which is how Nurrungar information was used during the Gulf war, now by the Defence Minister's admission.

But most of my questions to the Minister today remain unanswered. What about sharing information with other nations? I specifically asked that of the Minister in my question today, and because I had not given him notice he did not answer. These are meant to be questions without notice and one would think the Minister in charge of foreign affairs would know enough about his portfolio to be able to answer a question about this matter when it has been so much in the news lately. I asked him particularly: does the current proposal, if indeed there is one, extend to the British, the French, the Chinese or other countries concerned about the proliferation of ballistic missiles? There are 20 or so other countries either approaching or with ballistic missile capability. Are they also going to be privy to information gleaned through Pine Gap and Nurrungar? It would not be a bad idea if, as I said, it was to be used for peaceful purposes. What about the power of veto resting with Australia? That part of the question, of course, was totally ignored. Of course, it is far too embarrassing because we know very well that Australia has never in the past insisted on the power of veto and, as I framed it in my question today, if the joint facilities were used, if information from them was used in a regional war situation that the Australian Government did not approve—a long shot I know but, as I said, we must live in hope that such things are possible—what about that? What about the situation if the Soviet Union was privy to information from Nurrungar? Would the Soviets be able to use that for use of ballistic missiles against one of the republics within the Soviet Union in their internal conflict situation, which could escalate? Would Australia use the power of veto in that situation? The Minister absolutely ignored that part of the question.

If, as the Minister for Defence would have us believe, we have an independent foreign policy—as he was so proudly proclaiming at the launch of his new book just two days ago—Australia should have the power of veto. After all, these are bases on our soil. Do we automatically get involved in any conflict which the United States gets involved with? I know that we have not actually had anything to say of a negative kind about their adventures in Korea, Vietnam, Granada or the Gulf, and that is an unfortunate part of our history. It could occur in the future that we do not actually agree with the Americans. Are they going to pass on the information to other nations with whom they are in alliance but with whom we are not, as happened in the Gulf war? Australia's so-called policy of neutrality was breached during the Gulf war by the United States passing on information to its allies with whom we have no defence agreements. Now that is not a situation of a country which has an independent foreign policy. The Minister for Defence, of course, also likes to claim that we have an independent defence capability within an alliance framework. There is nothing independent about either, when, as this fiasco reveals, neither Minister is clear about what is going on regarding US bases on Australian soil. It is an absolute disgrace.

The only good report in today's news is that President Bush will not be visiting Australia next month. Thank goodness. The taxpayers might be saved a bit of taxpayers' money. It was going to cost at least $1m for members of the House of Representatives to be brought back to Canberra so that they could kowtow and ooh and ah for President Bush, as well as provide President Bush with the opportunity to address a joint sitting of parliament. This is not the Australian way of doing things when visiting heads of state come here. But this is what the Prime Minis-

SPEECH.PARA: ter was preparing to turn on for the President of the United States. Of course, we have already spent heaps of money on advance security preparations, and that cannot be recouped. However, thankfully, we will be spared the humiliating spectacle of our Prime Minister grovelling to the United States President on Australian soil, and that is a small mercy for which we must be grateful.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the tax threshold for: (a) a single person; and (b) a married person receiving a part or full Australian age pension.
(2) With married age pensioner couples, can the individual thresholds be shared up to the total limit for both couples; if so, what are the details.

(3) Do the same conditions prevail for Australian residents who are in receipt of a United Kingdom pension only, if not, what (are) the conditions and what is the rationale for having different rules for pensioners from other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) The income tax rates schedule for pensioners is the same as for taxpayers generally, and provides a tax free threshold of $5,400. In addition, persons who qualify for a full or part Australian Social Security pension have access to the pensioner rebate, which can extinguish tax liabilities where income is in excess of the $5,400 tax free threshold. In 1991-92, the pensioner rebate will enable single pensioners to earn non-pension income of up to $42 per week and married pensioners up to $74 per week combined, and pay no income tax. The rebate is not identical to additional tax free threshold as the rebate is progressively withdrawn where incomes exceed these levels.
The estimated maximum taxable incomes in 1991-92, at which a pensioner is eligible for the full rebate and therefore, not liable to pay income tax are as follows:
single—$10,065
married—$8,500
married—(living apart owing to illness or infirmity)—$9,805
Rebate entitlements are reduced by 12.5 cents for each dollar of taxable income in excess of these thresholds, which are termed 'rebate thresholds'.

(2) Since 1989-90, a married age pensioner has been able to benefit from any unused pensioner rebate of his or her spouse. In effect, when unused rebate is transferred it is combined with the taxpayer's original rebate and a new rebate threshold that allows full utilisation of the combined rebate is calculated, ie there is a transfer of the unused rebate threshold.
The unused rebate threshold transferred is:
the difference between the spouse's taxable income and the rebate threshold; or
if the taxable income of the spouse is below the general tax-free threshold, the difference between the general tax-free threshold and the rebate threshold.
The unused rebate and associated rebate threshold are transferred automatically in the assessment process.

(3) Access to the pensioner rebate is based on the same age and residency requirements as for an Australian pension. Retired persons, including those in receipt of a United Kingdom pension, who satisfy the age and residency requirements are eligible to receive a full or part Australian pension, at a level determined by the pensioner income and assets tests. Those who are in receipt of a taxable Australian repatriation or social security pension, would be eligible for the pensioner rebate, at a level determined by their taxable income. Those who are not in receipt of an Australian repatriation or social security pension, would not be eligible for the pensioner rebate.
Restricting access to the pensioner rebate in this way ensures consistent treatment with eligibility requirements for social security benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 24 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it recognised that some ex-seamen from HMAS Sydney, and similar vessels, are now suffering from asbestosis-related conditions;
(2) if so, is the Government considering, or proposing compensation for such individuals;
(3) and if so, what avenues should an ex-serviceman who has discovered he is suffering from an asbestosis-related disease follow to apply for compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has recognised that some former members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF), including ex-seamen from the HMAS Sydney, and similar vessels, are now suffering from asbestos-related conditions.

(2) Should it be shown that the member was exposed to asbestos in the course of his/her service and as a result of that exposure has contracted an asbestos-related condition, he/she would receive either a pension under the Veterans' Entitlement (VE) Act 1986 or compensation under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation (CERC) Act 1988.

As there is some overlap in the coverage provided by the VE Act and CERC Act for peacetime service and coverage for operational service is under the VE Act, potential claimants are encouraged to lodge claims under both the VE and CERC Acts. Those claims are then decided independently. In these cases, full benefits under both are not payable, but the compensation benefits under the CERC Act will be offset against any pension payable for the same condition under the VE Act.
(3) The member should lodge a claim with the Defence Compensation Section and/or the Department of Veterans' Affairs in his/her capital city. Claim forms are available from the respective offices.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister seen volume 11, no. 3 of Environment published in January 1990 by the Environment Centre of Western Australia (Inc.).
(2) Has it been noted that, despite one engineer's disclaimer, this publication advocates industrial sabotage including the `spiking' of trees, a practice which can maim or kill timber workers.

(3) Will the Minister immediately terminate all Commonwealth Government financial assistance to the Environment Centre of Western Australia (Inc.); if not, is it Government policy to subsidise industrial sabotage and environmental terrorism.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) It is assumed that this is a reference to a book review by Markus Green of the second edition of Ecodefence: A Field Guide to Monkeywrenching by Dave Foreman and Bill Haywood (eds). According to the reviewer, the book is a guide to the strategy, tactics and techniques of ecological defence known as `monkeywrenching' or `ecotage'. One of the activities described is the nail spiking of trees.

I share the honourable senator's concern that the reviewer's failure to condemn and discourage such dangerous 'monkeywrenching' activities as spiking trees and, indeed, all forms of industrial sabotage, in the cause of ecological defence is irresponsible, even if, as suggested in the review, there is a frivolous connotation in the way in which the book's authors offer them.
It is noted that the editorial policy of Environment is as follows: ``The views expressed in this magazine are not necessarily those of the editors or the Environment Centre Management Committee''.

The Government does not condone or subsidise the activities described in the book review. I am not aware that the Environment Centre of Western Australia has engaged in them. Commonwealth financial assistance is only provided to the Centre for administrative purposes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of Fraser Island

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories upon notice, on 14 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) In the $38 million Federal/State compensation package announced for those affected by Fraser Island, will any businesses not associated with the timber industry, but who are adversely affected by World Heritage Listing be compensated along with those affected in the timber industry.
(2) Will businesses involved in the mining industry be compensated by the Federal/State Government Fraser Island World Heritage compensation package.
(3) Did the World Heritage Listing affect industries other than the timber industry in the case of Fraser Island.

(4) Do businesses adversely affected by World Heritage Listing of Fraser Island, but which are not directly involved in the timber industry, have a legitimate claim for compensation; if so, what steps are being taken to compensate such businesses.

(5) In the case of a business on Fraser Island involved in the mining industry which has suspended operations temporarily because of world mineral prices, would it be eligible for compensation, given that World Heritage Listing would prohibit any future mining activity and therefore render a previously valuable asset virtually worthless.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer

PARA.TAB: (1) to (5) The Commonwealth Government has decided to provide a total of $16.5 million to the Queensland Government in 1991-92 and the two subsequent years, as a conditional grant to supplement Queensland's own expenditure on structural adjustment assistance in the Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region. An agreement is currently being drafted for consideration by both Governments covering the detailed terms and conditions of this grant.

Management of the assistance program is the responsibility of the Queensland Government, and decisions about what particular projects are to be funded will be made by that Government. The use of Commonwealth funds will be subject to agreed terms and conditions, and the Commonwealth will require that Queensland provide it with acquittal details relating to the expenditure of Commonwealth funds.
The honourable senator should therefore contact the appropriate Queensland Minister to obtain any additional information he may require.
